Without the sweeping aerial shots and the rest of the highly impressive camerawork, the documentary doesn't add up to more than standard, harmless wilderness fare for the kiddos.
It's just a shame you can't turn the voiceover off and tone down some of the orchestral accompaniment - the African Cats footage itself is dramatic enough alone.
Add a cool narration by the incomparable Samuel L. Jackson, though, and you have something really special.
African Cats' simplistic view of the African outback is far more dramatic and emotionally engaging than it is education.
The vistas of the African safari are stunning.
The most likely of Disneynature's three films to actually enthrall and captivate younger children.
Do you love the death penality and hate lawyers? Then don't miss this movie.
Sanders inspires joy in life's redemption and anger towards the ludicrous ways some states treat the exonerated.
Directed with compassion and outrage.
A powerfully affecting documentary on the subject of wrongful convictions overturned by DNA evidence.
An evenhanded but nonetheless startling depiction of a system that isn't merely blind -- it's deaf, dumb and stupid, as well.
A compelling look at a flawed system.
An extraordinary documentary about injustices rectified and innocent men set free after years in prison.
After Innocence doesn't inspire much confidence in the American legal system.
Evokes the quote, 'A liberal is a conservative that's been arrested.'
Both riveting and disturbing.
Calm, deliberate and devastating, Jessica Sanders's documentary confirms many of the worst fears about weaknesses in the American criminal-justice system.
The film cuts away from such personal stories too quickly, eager to sell us on airy, unjustified claims.
A powerful indictment of a judicial system too anxious to close cases, and then close ranks when someone tries to reopen them.

The film avoids being just a promo piece for the Project by focusing on the former prisoners' poignant personal stories, which include rebuilding their lives, campaigns against the death penalty and getting compensation for law enforcement's mistakes.
Taylor does her cause no real favors by trotting out only the most articulate, most clearly railroaded exonerees.
The moral purity of After Innocence is so overwhelming that it simply leaves you with nothing to say or do. It's kind of beyond criticism.
In her clear and compelling film, Sanders lets the innocents do the talking.
the grotty details of the political and legal muck miring the entire process are nowhere to be found
Sanders' report from a new frontier in American jurisprudence is filled with the hopeful, haunted look of men who won't easily be forgotten.
Even-handed but quietly devastating.
[A] rousing, quietly outraged documentary.
While the film is rich in fascinating, factual information, the most remarkable aspect of After Innocence is its unfailing humanity.

A strikingly varied collection of individual stories with a chilling common thread: the ease with which the criminal justice system can and does fail law-abiding, innocent Americans each and every day.
...the type of work that should inspire social reform
Come Oscar night, After Innocence will almost certainly trump them all. It's not necessarily better than any of the others, but its call for social awareness rings out bolder and rises higher.
Deeply touching and overwhelmingly sad.
[Documaker] Jennifer Sanders builds a solid foundation in making the point that, sometimes, our system of justice does the wrong thing, no matter how well meaning.
Each lost face in the documentary is a burning reminder of the human toll when our justice system succumbs to its imperfections.
Sanders is more interested in specific human struggles than in larger political points, but she knows these men form a mosaic with a message that's unmistakable.
The embittered men make fascinating subjects. Although innocent, they have been deeply scarred by their prison years.
Informative (we learn, for example, that exonerees are generally given no follow-up assistance upon release, as parolees are) and deeply moving.
Not a special pleader but is fairly special, because Sanders gives it the pressure of straight moral conviction.
Sanders has an important message, unfortunately diluted by unimaginative shooting and insufficient editing.
...terrific agitprop journalism/analysis...
This is no-frills filmmaking and may be a little talky, but it's also very well-made, powerful stuff, and it should be seen by anyone who has questions about the American justice system.
After Innocence is, without making it overly obvious, anti-death penalty on the grounds that a just society cannot afford to make any mistakes that we cannot attempt to rectify.
[The] stories of injustice and perseverence [will] stick in the memory after watching this uncluttered and compelling film.
Despite its flaws After Innocence raises staggering questions about virtually every aspect of the criminal-justice system.
You'll probably like it and wish it were better.
Eye-opening.
After Innocence is a crusading documentary driven by DNA testing that's brought freedom for men who served years in prison for crimes they didn't commit.

The scope of the problem, with likely thousands of innocent people incarcerated thanks mostly to errant eyewitness testimony, should give pause to anyone who thinks that life is as simple as black and white, innocent and guilty.
A rough but engrossing sketch of what freedom feels like, and what it costs, for seven men who've endured that national nightmare.
Both sorrowful and uplifting.
Documentary shines a scientific spotlight on the criminal justice system's dirty little secret via ten tragic cases of mistaken identity, each an unfortunate rush to judgment.
An advertorial rather than a solid piece of investigative journalism.
Powerful docu on post-prison lives of falsely accused.
The subject matter and content is so moving and thought-provoking that it hardly matters if the movie is a technical achievement.
a handsomely produced film that doesn't explore new territory or forge ahead with new insight, but is useful, nonetheless, as a primer on the history of the period
"Lesbians! We're everywhere! Lesbiana! Yo soy lesbiana!"
All the same, broken as it is, it still just about functions as a gentle, well-meaning reminder to be thankful for what you've got, rather than fearful at the prospect of losing it.
An out-of-work insurance man makes ends meet by turning to armed robbery in this overwrought and preposterous recession-era morality play from editor turned director Saar Klein.
Beautifully shot but disappointingly slack, Things People Do is ultimately as dull and forgettable as its title.
Moral ambiguity is center stage, and the film ultimately succeeds by sending audiences home to ponder their own levels of sin.
[The film] has much to recommend, including gorgeous New Mexico landscapes, sumptuous digital cinematography and -- as we might expect from Klein -- virtuoso editing.
Scanlon's desperate dive into a life of armed robbery is simply not believable, despite Bentley's best efforts.
If you can avoid dwelling on its derivative qualities, "After the Fall" has its own case to make about how far the middle class has fallen - and continues to slide.
"After the Fall" belongs to a type of movie that is too lazy to connect the dots and fill in the blanks between its supposedly teachable moments.
A substandard "crime drama" that reeks of the Idiot Plot Syndrome.
A film that could only succeed by sorting through gradually darkening shades of gray works exclusively in embarrassingly bold strokes.
Fall isn't going to cure the world's ills, but it does define a few of them to satisfaction, creating an engrossing journey into extremity without ringing all the obvious bells on the way down.
The basic story's narrative and psychological simplicity - characters stating their beliefs over and over again - becomes an increasing burden.
Forgettable...Bentley is bland, first scene to last, and thanks to its subject, the film is instantly dated
There are hints along the way of the socioeconomic strife that Klein wants to explore, yet they become lost in a muddled screenplay that doesn't establish sympathy for its protagonist or his plight.
Filled with convenient turns and easily attainable avenues of retribution, the film ultimately seems like an archaic example of the dangerous follies of patriarchy.
They're not heroes and they're not demons. After Tiller is an important reminder of the personal stories of doctors and mothers that can get lost in an issue as divisive as abortion.
"No body wants a fucking abortion" exclaims one of the doctors, and this is at the heart of the tough decisions that are played out every day within each clinic

After Tiller is not an important film just because of its political and cultural relevance, but because of its humane and compassionate approach to telling the stories of these doctors, their work and the women that they seek to help.
The directors are smart enough to understand that no matter how strongly you believe in a position, that belief is probably more shaded than a one-word "Yes" or "No."
A down-to-earth, non-sensational look at the only four doctors in the U.S. who perform third trimester abortions
A sensitive and intelligent documentary about the compassion and heroism of four doctors.
It gives a true sense of how the forces of a hypocritically religious country has burdened countless young women with a lifetime of misplaced guilt.
Hard-nosed advocacy segues into lefty-evangelizing treacle as a cloying score accompanies a number of dewy scenes better suited to a maudlin Oprah Winfrey special.
The film is warm and scrupulous, like a sunny women's clinic.
"After Tiller" is impressive because it honestly presents the views of supporters of legal abortion, and is thus a valuable contribution to a public argument that is unlikely to end anytime soon.
Empathetic, intimate look inside late-term abortion clinics that focuses on the experiences of doctors and their patients.
Like the men and women it follows, who do the work that few others dare, 'After Tiller' takes a stand.

After Tiller's...true value comes from going inside these clinics, listening to the stories...and asking viewers to wrestle with the moral and ethical complexities of an issue that absolutists on both sides oversimplify.
After Tiller is an hour and a half of folks on their best behavior, presented as a candid portrait.
No matter which side of the abortion issue you're on, prepare to be emotionally devastated.
Addressing an issue many Americans are uncomfortable with, this informative documentary sheds light and humanity on reproductive rights in this country.
After Tiller's greatest failing is the way in which is fails to engage at length how entrenched the stalemate on abortion is.
"After Tiller" takes the politically divisive, emotionally charged issue of late-term abortions and portrays it with grace, understatement and humanity.
"After Tiller" is groundbreaking in giving voice not only to the doctors, but to those who always seem to get overlooked in the high-volume political debate about this topic: the women themselves.
"Its unflinching portrayal of what can only be called battle fatigue is indelible.
A surprisingly warm abortion documentary that restores the human element to an irreducibly human dilemma.
It's an in-the-trenches exploration of bravery.
The film is a welcome exploration of practical and philosophical matters seldom broached across the partisan divide.
After Tiller gives a human and compassionate face to a complex and touchy issue.
After Tiller takes a compassionate look at a highly impassioned situation.
It's humanizing and heartbreaking.
Wrenching yet illuminating. The film reveals the complex circumstances, emotions and practical aspects behind the (third-trimester abortion) procedure.
A documentary that may infuriate those who find what these doctors do unconscionable, but that provides a rare forum for these dedicated, complex professionals to have their say.
The movie takes a calm and intellectual approach to an inflammatory subject, elevating what could have easily come off as propaganda into a reasoned and thoughtful work of journalism.
Compelling, revealing [its] subjects as sympathetic human beings simply by observing and talking to them about their work and their lives.

This is not a balanced doc -- of the little time given to the anti-abortion movement, most of it is from news footage -- but it is an important look at the lives of those who risk their own lives to perform what they see as a necessary service.
After Tiller movingly dramatizes another side effect of the job: how difficult it can be for the doctors to not internalize the sadness of the women who walk through their doors.
What makes this well-edited film compelling are the stories of the patients and the agonizing moral quandaries that the doctors express in doing their work.

It's a calm, thoughtful film about an incendiary subject, and it has a clear point of view: to allow these doctors (and some of their patients, who we hear but don't see) to explain why they do what they do.
Simultaneously tough and compassionate, it's a fine addition to the debate.
This wrenching documentary, profiling the four doctors who still provide third-trimester abortions in the U.S., is remarkable for being so level-headed.
Wrenching portrait of life and death decisions where even the definition of "life" is emotionally laden for doctors and pregnant women considering abortion.

"After Tiller" does viewers the great service of providing light where there's usually only heat, giving a human face and heart to what previously might have been an abstract issue or quickly scanned news item.
Moving, thought-provoking documentary.
If After Tiller does not feel grim, despite the overwhelming presence in it of death and mourning, that's perhaps because it is so much a film about intimacy and trust.
You may or may not be convinced, but you will be affected.

This is one of the best films I've seen this year. The access to doctors, their staffs, patients and families is very impressive. It has a lot of emotional power and it plays the abortion issue right down the middle.
Its strength lies in its ability to coax out the personalities behind the arguments, and to show us that, at the heart of every such controversy, there are vulnerable human beings.
We can see how they wrestle and it's immeasurably moving because they've given it endless consideration and still put themselves in harm's way.
Rarely is this issue presented so fairly and without the requisite hysteria.
It's a grim story.
A laudably even-handed examination of a highly charged subject.
The story of four women and their attempts to uphold abortion rights in the US makes for compelling, if horrifying viewing.
Directors Martha Shane and Lana Wilson in this topical documentary ably tackle in a fair-minded and detailed way the controversial issue of third-trimester abortions.
The film goes about its grave task with compassion, basic professionalism, and discretion.

This documentary portrait of abortion doctors in America, particularly those who perform late-term abortions, looks at those who do important, compassionate work, but isn't as engaging as it should be.
More than simply informative (which it most certainly is), After Tiller is a reminder that seeing eye-to-eye is rarely as impossible as we might think.
Engaging and thoughtful, After Tiller's examination of its main subjects forms a documentary that wisely treats its subject with more curiosity than dogma.

The film succeeds, however, because it manages to rise above the controversy surrounding legalized abortion in America and objectively presents what's at stake here for the doctors and women involved.
I understand that "After Tiller" is intended to be a pro-choice film and have no problem with that. It would be a stronger one if it took the other side more seriously.
You may not leave the theater with a different view, but that's not the point. A good film is one that starts a conversation and provokes thought, and After Tiller is certainly one of those films.
There is nothing easy about After Tiller. Not the watching or the telling.

After Tiller is undoubtedly at its most compelling when stripped down to doctor-patient level. The majority of the testimonies from those individuals wishing to be considered for the third-trimester process are truly heartbreaking.
An essential piece of media for understanding the issue.
After Tiller is, to put it simply, a surprisingly boring documentary considering how sensitive of a topic abortion is.
This portrayal of [the doctors'] work, dedication, and grace under pressure is heart-breaking in so many ways.
[L]ooks at those who do important, compassionate work, but isn't as engaging as it should be.
It offers hardheaded commentary about the rigors of a dancer's life and how everyone who chooses a dance career is aware of its brevity.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: Even in a wheelchair, Le Clercq, who died in 2000 at age 71, commands authority with little more than her captivating, wicked smile.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: While it does profile the work of brilliant dancer, the film also contains two complex and moving love stories as well an account of a physically devastating tragedy followed by an extraordinary tale of struggle and survival.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: Flawed as it is, no balletomane should miss this one.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: Classical dance great Jacques d'Amboise calls Tanaquil LeClercq's style a "path to heaven." And this lovely documentary by Nancy Buirski makes clear that he's right.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: Illuminating, profound and poignant.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: "Afternoon of a Faun" brings to light Le Clercq's simultaneously depressing and inspirational story.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: [As Le Clercq falls to polio, director Nancy] Buirski digs up footage from the past of people encased in iron lungs or floating in nebulous wonderlands - outside-the-box visual cues that turn the film momentarily phantasmagoric.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: Buirski takes us on an emotional journey, although the start may seem slow to people unfamiliar with the ballet world or Le Clercq's story.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: "Here, in a few minutes of black-and-white footage, are a gaze, a touch, a few steps and a look out at the audience that create an unforgettable impression. "
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: What's most fascinating about "Afternoon of a Faun" - and what the movie could spend more time delving into - is ballet's grueling and fleeting nature.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: Director Nancy Buirski not only is able to give rare insights into the dance world but a compelling tale of love, friendship and perseverance.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: [A] strangely haunting, often heartbreaking new documentary.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: Mythic, indeed.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: A spooky, heartbreaking documentary about Tanny le Clercq.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: Buirski easily affirms that the dancer's angular sensuality was but one aspect of her enduring creative power.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: It interviews friends and confidants, provides glimpses of what she was like as a person and, best of all, shows us clips of her dancing, which tell us so much of what we need to know.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: A fascinating story of American ballet and one of the greatest ballerinas in the world.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: A hopelessly insular work [that] affirms the talent of its subject, but frustratingly fails to establish a cleanly delineated backdrop or emotional throughline for a general audience.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: As tragedy of the woman whose whole life was the hothouse of the dance -- including narrating her wistful, matter-of-fact letters and journals during treatment -- the doc exploring the myth of Le Clercq will be a balletomane's delight.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: Reminds us what the ballet world had for a time.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: Afternoon of a Faun is primarily the story of a woman loved, desired, objectified and watched by men.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: LeClerq, who lived her later years with a fierce independence, died in 2001; in this thoughtful, quiet film, she lives on.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: This 2013 profile of famed ballerina Tanaquil Le Clercq divides its running time between biographical information and synopses of creative achievements, but it doesn't aspire to anything more than the sum of its parts.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: "Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq" presents enough teasing glimpses into the dancer's personal and inner life to demand a fuller picture.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: It is the mythic resonance of her story that makes it a worthy subject a documentary. But it is the down-to-earth human touches that make "Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq" worth watching.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: A beautiful tribute to a rare artist with an even rarer spirit.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: The film would be valuable for collecting this footage... even if its lapses as documentary cinema and storytelling device were far more serious than they are.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: The film exists as both a chronicle of her astonishing talent and her formidable spirit.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: Afternoon of a Faun celebrates Tanny's unique physical gifts and profiles her phenomenal career in-depth, it more importantly gives the feeling that we know her.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq

review_content: Painful but essential.
As a filmmaker, psychotherapist Bloch puts Germany, Israel and the Palestinians on the couch and lets them see the one awful memory that binds them - trauma.
[Bloch is] an excellent interviewer, asking difficult questions about what her subjects think of Israel, the Holocaust and the Jewish people, then carefully considering the answers.
While Bloch's emotions and thoughts about the Holocaust and the Israeli occupation are deeply felt, the documentary's finer points are a little less clear.
No matter, it's a timely and essential portrait.

By being willing to subject herself to the same analysis as others, [Ofra] Bloch gives the viewer more room to appreciate the ubiquity of the problem, and the opportunity to account for any bias she may have.
This film is therapy for all involved.
... commendably even-handed and persuasive thanks to some thoughtful subjects.
The film is a good start, but such an important artist deserves a more rigorous portrait.
Doc about dissident artist is long on political friction, short on art.
Let's hope Klayman gets to make a sequel.
A necessary, compelling and very funny introduction to the eponymous artist as well as a good point of access for Americans who know little of China's creative activists.
Alison Klayman's documentary briskly tells his story, much of it recorded by Ai in his own documentaries, on his Web site, and on his Twitter feed.
Alison Klayman has a fascinating subject for her first feature -- the media savvy Chinese activist artist who lays his career, family and life on the line for civil rights.
The director's clear-minded approach allows her subject's more challenging aesthetic-political mix to shine through, even if it's at the inevitable expense of her own filmmaking proclivities.
His spiritedness makes the darker places his story goes all the more affectingly tragic.
He radiates a mischievous sense of the absurdity - and necessity - of one man tossing stones at a regime this gigantic.
A useful primer, though it also focuses a bit more on the activism than on the art.

He may still seem enigmatic, but we don't need to know his deepest thoughts. The intensity of his daily life and the persecution he continues to face is more than enough to understand who he is and what he is enduring.
Klayman had full access to Ai, 55, following him around for two years. The sweetest footage involves Ai and his mother.
Ai Weiwei is too commanding and fascinating a figure to ignore, and Never Sorry is an excellent showcase for why he matters to the world.
Ai Weiwei is a crucial figure of East-West cultural communication and contemporary history, whose middle finger extended at the centers of power stands for a rising tide of global discontent.
The fluidity and convenience of digital moviemaking tools explain some of its freshness, as does Ms. Klayman's history as a budding documentarian.
The film's greatest distinction is its intimacy.
One can't help wishing the subject would make his own, more complex cinematic self-portrait. But for now, Klayman has provided a valuable introduction to a man everyone should know.
Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry accomplishes what the best works of this sort do: Take a great, compelling, widely known story and make it deeper, fuller and better.
Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry is a portrait of a brave (or simply stubborn) eccentric in action.
A compelling documentary about the Chinese contemporary artist who seems to spend his life on a blade's edge, dancing on a knife that's in the hands of the government.
Klayman acquaints us with the man behind the decisions, an extraordinarily down-to-earth yet cosmopolitan figure, full of mischief, courage and defiance.
Offers a good introduction to the career of this fascinating man who is no shrinking violet.

Terrific documentary about the recent headline-grabbing dissident Chinese artist-activist is a provocative portrait of an amusing, even self-deprecating man of wry smiles, much wisdom and not a little mischief.
Ai Weiwei is sorry now - just as sorry as every American citizen living under a similarly merciless form of militarized government.
Top-drawer documentary about the art and activism of a Chinese artist who yearns for freedom.
As much as Never Sorry reveals about its central subject, it reveals just as much about the place where he lives, and the way demands for freedom find methods to limbo under oppression.
Doesn't mask its awe of the man, who comes off as a cross between a wise Buddha-figure and Santa Claus
As this sometimes haphazard documentary shows, Ai won't stop talking. Or blogging. Or tweeting.
A vital, informative wake-up call that will make you feel equally enraged and inspired.
The finale, as Ai's Twitter tirades lead to a serious human-rights breach, will make your blood boil.
You come away with an appreciation of the abstraction, scale and daring of Ai's art and, even more, a sense of the living man in his courage, humor and restlessness. It's an invigorating experience.
A sobering, cautionary tale.

One of the most engagingly powerful movies of the year almost completely on the strength of Ai's rumpled charisma and the confusion it creates in the bureaucratic mindset of the Chinese Communist Party.
Though he has paid the price, Ai is a pathfinder in this new phenomenon in tactical insurrection. Never Sorry is a new-style profile in 21st-century courage.

Ai admits that he's become "a brand for liberal thinking and individualism," though that's nothing to be ashamed of -- at this point, his Warholian talent for self-promotion may be the only thing keeping him alive.
Structurally ragged but engrossing documentary [about] a courageous provocateur with a gift for cleverly ridiculing a dangerous regime.
An excellent, revelatory new documentary. Weiwei proves a thoroughly compelling subject.
The story is enthralling, but it's not over, and there's no telling where it's going. Which makes what we see on screen all the more involving.
Klayman exploits the opportunity to follow a man at the eye of a cultural and political storm, although more detail on his creative process and private life would have welcome.
In terms of getting his message out to a wider audience, this film simply and effectively serves as part of the cause.
Affable and unpretentious, Ai comes across as a cagey operator whose candor is very appealing.
He is heroic.
It's likely to change the way you think about art and politics and the state of China today.

The boundaries between performance and protest are virtuosically, vitally fuddled in this stirring documentary chronicling three years in the life of Ai Weiwei, the outspoken Chinese artist and dissident.
Using archival footage dating back to Ai's adventures in the New York art world in his 20s, Klayman traces his evolution as a creator and as an activist.
The artist repudiated the repudiation. Art had, as art always should have, the last word.
Fascinating account of Weiwei's practice and politics that gives centre stage to his charismatic personality.
This is how a documentary portrait should be done.
Klayman's all-access, warts-and-all coverage of this artist's struggles with the State represents an extension of Ai's own ideals about transparency and freedom of expression.

[H]as a sense of the gloss to it: Ai is such a complex man, and he's operating in an environment that is alien to most Westerners, and so at every turn here, I wanted to get into much more depth than Klayman takes us to.
A powerful picture, yet, even more impressively, it treats art like a vessel for communication and meaningful exploration, not just as a stepping stone to cult fame.
His willingness to speak out despite severe consequences is inspiring, and his recent silence speaks almost as loudly as his work in calling attention to China's repressive tactics.
This essential, finely honed biographical portrait is jollied along by all the ironies and complexities of modern China.
Who doesn't hate it when critics say, "this is an important documentary you must see!" Well, Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry is a critically important documentary you need to see.
Well worth seeing.
Though we might wish for more insight or explanation, Klayman's film remains an incredible document of a courageous individual who the Chinese officials would prefer to make disappear.
A movie that somehow mixes apprehension for Ai with a feeling of warmth and, certainly, fun.
A lively, informative, funny and inspirational portrait of a courageous, charismatic, highly original man.
This riveting documentary deserves consideration for year-end awards. Klayman gained unprecedented access to this very photogenic man with a dynamic personality.
The film's recurring theme is of an artist on a perpetual hunt for transparency, in his country and abroad.
A powerful film that teaches us as much about ourselves as it does it's subject, "Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry," is a sure bet to be nominated for an Oscar come January 2013.
An unprecedented inside look at Chinese politics and a fascinating tour of modern art at the same time.
Klayman deserves a lot of credit for being in the right place at the right time with the right person. Ai is a treat to follow around, and his courage is clearly more than a pose.
Even if you don't like documentaries as a rule, I'm betting you'll like Ai Weiwei himself so much that you'll be glad you took the time to get to know him through this film.
... straightforward, entertaining and provocative documentary about the titular Chinese artist
A fascinating portrait of a modern artist and activist trying to make a difference within China's repressive political system.
Alison Klayman's remarkable film about China's leading 'digital dissident' fully illustrates the talents of a man who often does the opposite of what you'd expect.
The struggle for free speech in China is given sharp, sobering, disturbing voice through the struggles of cutting edge, digitally savvy, Twitter-loving artist Ai Weiwei.
A compelling documentary that explodes proper and stuffy notions of what a foreign intellectual dissident looks and sounds like.
Klayman never demonizes the authoritarian Chinese government, as her purpose seems to be to show how difficult it is to be a rebel in such a closed society as China.
The film is about the power and limits of art.
Ai Weiwei is such a laid back, calm and yet mischievous spirit that the film takes on a whole different, almost joyous tone.
To say Ai Weiwei is an interesting character is an understatement. He is an unconventional social activist and a thorn in the side of the authoritarian Chinese Communist Party.
Invigorating.

"Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry" is tightly focused on Ai, touching only superficially on the larger Chinese art scene and the political context in which he works. That said, the film is still highly informative.

Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry teaches us, if nothing else, that its subject will never stop speaking truth to power, whether in the form of a 140-character tweet or a large-scale piece of architecture that towers over the tiny men who try to keep him quiet.
Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry is both a perfect introduction to an endlessly intriguing individual, and a unveiling of sorts for fans who know the artist solely through the online arena.

Every art documentary has to look beyond the bubble of the artist. Ai Weiwei towers above the others, not just because of the artist's brilliant work...but because he keeps pushing art beyond its boundaries, out into the world.
If you are not in the slightest bit moved by it, then perhaps political and artistic apathy has sadly taken hold.

A fascinating follow-up to Never Sorry, Ai Weiwei: The Fake Case considers the implications of one's political actions in a protective state like China, and doubles down on letting one's voice be heard in spite of the consequences.
In spite of the intermittent frustrations ... Weiwei remains a captivating figure.
Accessible documentary serves as useful introduction to and informative update on an artist who's seldom out of the headlines for long.
The Fake Case contextualizes Ai's struggle by positioning it in relation to his family history.
With the aid of Johnsen's doc to overcome the obstacles China has put in his path, however, Ai's voice carries louder than ever before.

In The Fake Case, Danish filmmaker Andreas Johnsen connects with Chinese artist Ai Weiwei after his 81-day solitary confinement for subversion of state power, and deftly portrays a man untrammeled by his opponents.
"If I don't share my voice," he says, "then I am dead already." It sounds almost like a dare.
Mr. Johnsen offers viewers the challenge and pleasure of an important artist's company, and a chance to appreciate anew his wisdom, his wit and his bravery.
An enlightening Danish documentary about one of the world's most famous and creative human rights activists.
China's government can't handle dissident artist Ai Weiwei. He turns every move to suppress him into brilliant conceptual art.
Intimate portrait of a stubborn artist. . .demonstrates the power of government control to inflict disruptive stress, the power of art to transform repression into optimism.

The Fake Case isn't an official sequel to Alison Klayman's 2012 documentary Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry, but it might as well be, as this fascinating and necessary coda picks up right where that earlier film left off ...
Johnsen intimately chronicles the fascinating push-pull of Ai's daily existence: the man he truly is now contrasted with the man he hopes to become once again.

The film quietly and slowly reveals a man struggling internally to find the right response to the restrictions imposed on him and determining that to stop speaking out would itself be a kind of death.
Although expertly edited, Johnsen's film, whose soundtrack ends with Nina Simone's "Feeling Good," presents a less effective portrait of Ai than Klayman's does.
The film is not terribly involving except to Ai's followers.
Remarkably intimate and astute.
Ai comes across as highly intelligent, weary, extremely wary of outsiders but with a puckish sense of humor.
Heartening chronicle of the further "crazy dreams" of an artist who doesn't intend to have freedom defined for him by the state.

Ai granted Johnsen significant access to his personal and professional lives following his release, including his tender interactions with his young son, and the film's intimate nature recalls the verite style of Ai's own video work.
While little more than an update on an ongoing dispute, The Fake Case is a welcome chance to catch up with the quirky artist's heroic struggle for freedom.

Chinese dissident Ai Weiwei is a lot of things: Artist, activist, father, son. What he's not, is dull. But you'd never know it judging by Andreas Johnsen's somnambulant take on his subject's Sisyphean fight for human rights.
A unique portrait of an artist in turmoil.

The view from his high rise windows include the United States Embassy right next door, a reminder of the freedom he longs for in his native country. A freedom he knows can be taken away in the blink of an eye.
Ai Weiwei: The Fake Case finds its titular subject beaten but unbowed.
A source of inspiration and outrage, Fake Case is highly recommended for all viewers who value free expression.
A bold political statement, affirming the freedom of expression in a time when it can land an artist jail.
It's a fascinating portrait of a family that finds love after trauma.
Aida's secrets should be shared with the world. They're about more than just one family.

The remarkable tale it tells - of a family split up and dispersed to different continents, and the detective work required to figure out what had happened - turns this documentary into a fascinating mystery of reshuffled identities.
Viewers will likely feel the urge to contact a genealogist after seeing Alon and Shaul Schwarz's fascinating and moving documentary about amazing revelations concerning their own family.
Profoundly moving, warm, and captivating. A truly remarkable and unforgettable documentary.
One family's silences and lies unravel before our eyes in the gripping, intimate "Aida's Secrets."
"Aida's Secrets" starts out as a fairly straightforward documentary about reuniting two long-separated brothers, but directors Alon and Shaul Schwarz don't stop there.
Even though Aida's Secrets lacks a big, satisfying payoff, there are small joys along the way.

In that sense, "Aida's Secrets" carries a feeling of suspense that few documentaries achieve. The film's style is straightforward and intimate, eschewing fancy technique to focus on the gravity of its subject.
The camerawork and editing often leave something to be desired. Most of the time, this doesn't matter, because we are drawn into the mystery.

Some 6,000 rescued Jews celebrated every sweet breath and soon produced 1,300 babies. What follows is a a hell of a generational human story, one that speaks to determination, cruel bargains and sacrifice
Co-directors (and extended family members) Alon and Saul Schwarz use clever editing to parse out the genealogical twists and turns in the story, although a final-act surprise is left hanging.
In the end, this isn't just a story about one family fractured by the Holocaust, but about the German nurse and the South African kindergarten teacher who would affect the trajectory of the clan.

Aida's Secrets is not an incredibly artful doc...But the straight-ahead observation of this specific human story is powerfully emotional and affecting, particularly in the way it tracks the brothers' newfound relationship.

Aida's Secrets offers shocking moments, disappointment, and fulfillment while still finding ways to deepen the mystery of this fragile, elderly woman who lived a life that was both extraordinary and probably quite common in the aftermath of the Holocaust.
Broomfield frequently seems as willing as his subject to indulge in conspiracy theories and there often exists the queasy hunch that his interest in her feeds her sickness.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: As much a pointed and wise exploration of a documentarian's involvement in his subject matter as it is an angry indictment of the American judicial system.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: This is a chilling, extremely insightful documentary--not so much for what it tells us about Aileen Wuornos as for what it says about our society.

review_content: A fascinating portrait of the woman, and a damning one of the society in which she lived.

review_content: A profoundly disturbing film.

review_content: It makes for a tabloid account, albeit a deliciously droll sidebar to The Selling Of A Serial Killer.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Told what to think, the viewer is distanced by film acknowleging its film-ness.

review_content: The only reality here is that truth is slippery, and that's something Broomfield understands more than most documentary filmmakers working today.

review_content: Illuminates Wuornos' tragedy and eats into your mind.

review_content: She was guilty, no doubt, but as this immensely moving film makes clear, Aileen Wuornos was also heartbreakingly human.

review_content: As gripping and suspenseful as anything Hollywood is capable of turning out.

review_content: Might have been a good film, except that Broomfield had the inside track. His films are, ultimately, always about the making of his films.

review_content: An eloquent case against the death penalty, especially when imposed on the mentally incompetent.

review_content: Broomfield is mostly just shooting from the hip and missing as much as he scores

review_content: The filmmaker's ego and ethics aside, there's no denying the power of Wuornos' behavior here.

review_content: Broomfield's film is typically self-aggrandizing but filled with unsettling moments.

review_content: The director ... makes a compelling argument that Wuornos never got a fair deal from the legal system and that she should have been spared death because of insanity.

review_content: Except for the sermonizing, altogether a deeper, more interesting movie than Monster.

review_content: [Broomfield] makes an entertaining and at times even compelling argument, whatever his topic.

review_content: Even if she skirts the big questions, Wuornos is a riveting presence -- affable and articulate one minute, twitchy and petulant the next.

review_content: Marked by Broomfield's same stentorian, recurrently officious narration... but still a sharp, affecting portrait of monstrous underclass miasma.

review_content: An essential viewing companion to its dramatic narrative counterpart.

review_content: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer should be seen, probably before Monster. Maybe instead of Monster.

review_content: It's a far more gripping documentary than Broomfield's 1992 Wuornos film.

review_content: If you have the stomach for it, this engrossing documentary sheds additional light on a controversial figure whose case continues to incite debate.

review_content: Wuornos became, by the old standards of stark morality, evil, but was undeniably a classic victim and victimizer. Thanks to Broomfield and others, she is a sleepless night that endures.

review_content: Digs into the soul of this abused child, who never got the treatment she needed. Her eyes, radiating madness, will haunt your dreams.

review_content: Though one can question the movie's quality as a documentary ... Aileen raises such troubling issues that it stays, hellishly, in your mind.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Her intense denial is fascinating, and extremely sad, to watch.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: No one should have to endure the life that Aileen Wuornos led, and we leave the movie believing that if someone, somehow, had been able to help that little girl, her seven victims would never have died.

review_content: It does ... make a powerful argument against capital punishment, no matter which side of the debate you happen to take.

review_content: A valuable and insightful contribution to the mountain of Aileen Wuornos speculation and documentation.

review_content: [T]his movie literally gave me the chills.

review_content: Engrossing, educational, amusing and disturbing.

review_content: Does afford a real-life view of Wuornos during the days of her final appeal and her ultimate date with death.

review_content: It's clear Theron didn't so much resemble [Wuornos] as she did channel her deeply tormented soul, in a way that Broomfield never manages to do.

review_content: While I prefer more even-handed approaches to documentary film, there’s no denying the power of the footage, particularly that featuring [Aileen] Wuornos.

review_content: This compassionate documentary should be of strong interest to viewers of the previous Wuornos film or the current Monster.

review_content: Though unpleasant to watch, Life and Death of a Serial Killer presents a portrait of evil, betrayal and banality that's almost impossible to take your eyes off of.

review_content: Not even Charlize Theron's lauded portrayal of the accused can compete with the captivating genuine article, whose calculated professions of remorse barely conceal her festering rage at a lifetime of mistreatment.

review_content: A haunting exploration of a ruined and wasted life.

review_content: [Broomfield's] least exploitative, most personal work to date

review_content: For the fans left bereft by his 2012 death, it's impossible to imagine a more exquisite, honest, and beautifully detailed documentary about the life of Levon Helm than Jacob Hatley's Ain't in It for My Health.
movie_title: Ain't In It For My Health: A Film About Levon Helm

review_content: Despite his flashes of bitterness, the Helm captured here seems like a man at peace with where he ended up - however taxing the road that brought him, however many friends lost or discarded along the way.

review_content: An affectionate tribute and a gift for fans who grew fond of his company on records or at concerts and who would like a little bit more.
movie_title: Ain't In It For My Health: A Film About Levon Helm

review_content: Director Jacob Hatley clearly earned the complete trust of Helm's inner circle, enough to capture the icon's crusty humor, singular talent and significant bravery in the face of his fate.

review_content: It's a sympathetic portrait of an artist whose heart lay more with new work than old glories, right up to the end.
movie_title: Ain't In It For My Health: A Film About Levon Helm

review_content: Less than satisfying treatment of beloved musician, who never quite lets his guard down.

review_content: The portrait of the ailing artist is bittersweet, but when Helms sings or plays, the look on his face is pure joy.

review_content: And of all the figures - Bob Dylan, Gram Parsons, et al. - who smuggled those sepia-toned seeds into rock 'n' roll, Helm, was arguably the most authentic.

review_content: [A] bittersweet, frustratingly impressionistic documentary ...
