Tears will be shed, many of them surely genuine. Yet there's still something about this oversize spectacle, and Miles' ultimate place in it, that gives nagging pause.
Batkid Begins uses its unforced sentiment and real emotional depth to (at least temporarily) slay any misanthropic feelings or cynical thoughts.
It's a rare documentary that showcases the absolute best of humanity.
Plucky, upbeat and utterly lacking in cynicism -- much like the epic day this Make a Wish event went down.
Nachman's documentary does a great job of showing the many pieces that came into place for Miles' moment, but it doesn't look much at what's underneath it all.

Nachman has structured her film to illustrate how coming together for a cause can be at least as, if not more beneficial for the adults who helped make a small boy's dream come true than for the kid himself.
Contagiously joyous.
Batkid Begins is a story about good people doing better things, which makes everyone happy. Why is this something we keep forgetting?
... too often feels shallow and superficial, missing a chance to provide depth and context beyond the basics.
The footage is simultaneously spectacular and intimate, with plenty of adorable-child moments.
As a record of the event it's amiable enough, but also a bit ragged and more than a little self-satisfied.
Everybody got a bit of childhood back, not because of what they got but because of what they gave.
Batkid Begins has the feel of a barn-raising gone global.

The seams occasionally show, especially whenever the shy, overwhelmed Miles grows tired or reluctant - or whenever the easily defeated villains start to look like so many overstuffed dolls - but it's impossible to say "no" to this project.

At some point ... we notice Batkid Begins is also a way to call attention to other parties, massive Silicon Valley corporations that jump on the Batkid bandwagon - including Apple, Twitter, Facebook and, most suspiciously, Uber ...
There's plenty of space for cynicism in this bitter, cold world, but Batkid Begins makes a fine case for an authentically rare mass moment of everyone acting like a decent person.
It's great fun to watch, with even President Barack Obama getting in on the act, and Batman Begins can be enjoyed entirely on this basis.
Bring kleenex.

"Batkid" is a feel-good film, in the sense that the people who made this wish come true seem to feel pretty good about themselves. They certainly have a right to be satisfied: What they pulled off is impressive.

Celebrates a city united for fun and goodwill, and the rare, pronounced sense of play and energy adults are capable of rediscovering, as do those who toil excitedly and hopefully to give Miles 'a little bit of his childhood back.'

Though it's easy to contrast "Batkid Begins" with "Dear Zachary" - tears of heartache replaced with tears of joy - both are about coming out of tragedy with a positive outlook for the future & rewarding the often thankless task of being a great parent.
If watching "Batkid Begins" doesn't move you, I seriously don't know what will. And who doesn't love a five-year-old superhero?
For one day, at least, the optimists among us could revel in the good-heartedness of people the world over.
This is the kind stuff that you cannot make up.

There's a wealth of material to draw on, almost as if a documentary-to-be-named later was already on someone's mind. In any case, Nachman puts it all to good use, relaying the conception, planning, preparation and execution of the day.
Get ready to have your spirits lifted by Batkid Begins, the most heartwarming film you're going to see this year.

"Begins" journeys into the heart of charity and community support, clearing away the ugliness of the world for 80 minutes to bask in the glow of what was intended to be a block-wide event that eventually snowballed into a global phenomenon.
Unfortunately Batkid Begins is so rigidly upbeat that it begins to seem like one of those really cheesy Hallmark movies on TV.
Nachman, for her part, diligently tries not to lose sight of the child at the center of it all.
If you have the opportunity to see Batkid, I encourage you to buy a ticket. It won't change our world. But it could change us. Then we can improve the world. Batman would like that.
It's refreshing to see a film that's completely lacking in cynicism.
Cynics can carp. Let them. But don't be one of them.
The deeper we go into Dana Nachman's unquestioning, feature-length cheerleading film, the more uncomfortable I felt about the reaction of one person to that magical and overwhelming day. Miles.
It tells the story in a powerful and uncomplicated way.
With great cheer and good spirit, Batkid Begins tells a true story that will restore your faith in humanity.
I'm still not sure if it warranted a full length documentary, but [it] is a fine ode to Batman and the human condition.
The message of Batkid Begins is, to me, Cynics of the world? You lost.
Nachman understands the true value and meaning of Miles' story, and with luck Batkid Begins will keep his dream alive for years to come.
Sweet and winning and makes us all feel a little better about the world in which we live
Although Battle for Brooklyn gives voice to the project's supporters, there's little doubt which side Galinsky and Hawley are on.

Battle for Brooklyn provides a useful primer on the opposition to Atlantic Yards, but figures who might have made more compelling documentary subjects than the always on-message Goldstein crowd the sidelines.
Nothing propels a documentary like injustice, and Michael Galinsky and Suki Hawley's infuriating chronicle of an outer-borough David-versus-Goliath saga plays like a marathon of inequity.
This film should be discouraging and dismaying for people on all sides of the project, for what it says about oversize expectations and missed opportunities.

The Empire State's eminent domain laws are unusually loose, but most of the rest of this story is pertinent far beyond New York. Change a few names and add the next credit bubble, and a Brooklyn-style Battle could be headed to a neighborhood near you.

Most viewers should find the documentary Battle For Brooklyn gripping and provocative, no matter their opinions about eminent domain, historic preservation, or public dollars going to support private development.

Despite what other critics have said here, the movie allows the developers equal time. Of course, they hoist themselves on their own petards which you would expect. Anyhow, this is must-seeing for those concerned about the stranglehold of the rich on NY.
Brings us inside the lives it touches.
Not exactly inspiring.
Spins a compelling tale about the value of individual and collective resistance, even as it makes clear where power in our society really resides.
If you're a New Yorker, it's a mesmerizing story and for the most part Battle For Brooklyn, provides an engrossing history lesson on this controversial project.

A battle ordinarily requires two sides, yet this earnest, ungracefully reconstructed saga posits that opposition to the building of the New Jersey Nets' future home took place in a virtual vacuum, and that the fix was in from the start.

A powerful and surprisingly moving film about an important and little-reflected-upon topic; a telling snapshot of political maneuvering, and the tossed-around wrecking-ball weight of corporate might as it relates to individual rights.
Hawley and Galinsky, a longtime wife-and-husband documentary team, bring real suspense to the story, culled from many hundreds of hours of footage.
It's a familiar story, but that doesn't make it any easier to swallow.
Battle For Brooklyn is a telling snapshot of (offscreen) political maneuvering, and the tossed-around wrecking-ball weight of corporate might as it relates to individual rights.
Although not exactly even-handed, the movie proves a deft look at a reluctant crusader and how financial sway and political override can so effectively trump the power of the average citizen.
'A movie with a narrative' woven along a personal thread, Battle for Brooklyn squeezes drama even out of that person's repeatedly clicking a monitor 'refresh.'

Battle for Brooklyn earns its epic-sounding title, building, block by block, a sturdy, gritty little film about the impassioned fight to ensure development's directed by the local people and for the local people, not by a few overlords above all.

...despite the title of the doc, which conjures up a madcap, heartbreaking tale, the film is a mostly workmanlike biopic that unfortunately can never match the energy of the subject it's trying to capture
Booker sparkles in the archival performance clips, and director Lily Keber wisely homes in on his live solo performances, bringing out his character and talent.
A sympathetic portrait of a genuinely idiosyncratic, outrageous individual.
[A] richly enjoyable documentary tribute.
Bayou Maharajah is worth watching for the performance footage alone.

[Booker] backed a huge number of musicians.. But his solo work -- shown here in rollocking, flamboyant archive performances -- allowed him to give full flight to his infectious and innovative mix of jazz, blues and classical.
Overall, though, Keber's film feels like an honourable attempt to tidy up after and make order of its subject's spiralling chaos.
In the music business, 'legend' is an over-used word: see this and understand what it means.
movie_title: BB King: The Life of Riley

review_content: Conscientious documentary toasting and contextualising blues guitarist BB King's life and work.
movie_title: BB King: The Life of Riley

review_content: [An] authoritative British documentary on [King's] long, impressive career.
movie_title: BB King: The Life of Riley

review_content: An intuitive and appealing documentary about the life of one of the world's most recognised Blues musicians, but BB King: The Life of Riley sometimes grows a bit repetitive and its chronological sequence is rather bland.
movie_title: BB King: The Life of Riley

review_content: Too many people know this man as just the source vocalist from Moby's classic 'Natural Blues'; hopefully this will change that.
movie_title: BB King: The Life of Riley

review_content: [King] is unfailingly articulate, gentlemanly and modest but this is a movie where more music, less talk would definitely have been an improvement.
movie_title: BB King: The Life of Riley

review_content: It would have been nice if the movie had allowed voices less fannish than those of King's peers and childhood friends to make the case for the signficance of 'The King of the Blues.'
movie_title: BB King: The Life of Riley

review_content: A dignified and wistful look at the unusual life, difficult career and lasting influence of singer-songwriter Townes Van Zandt.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: A loving and beautifully rendered portrait of one of America's largely unheralded artists.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Loving but frank.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Margaret Brown has directed a tender, impressionistic film biography about the Texan singer-songwriter Townes Van Zandt.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Brown has put together a heartbreaking yet inspiring portrait of a transcendently tragic artist through home movies, family scrapbooks, live performances and interviews with ex-wives, record producers, and peers.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Both frustrating and touching.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: To her vast credit, Brown doesn't attempt to psychoanalyze Van Zandt, or linger over the dark times in his short life in Be Here to Love Me. She instead keeps the focus where it should be: on the lasting gift of Townes Van Zandt's 30-year career.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Brown's film evinces a tender, yet unsparing scrutiny of its subject's idiosyncrasies without getting too caught up in the romance of ruin.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: The songs burn with a dark fire, yet there are moments when Van Zandt is less Bob Dylan than David St. Hubbins.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: It's Van Zandt's family that provides the film's most memorable moments, from the second wife who declared life with him 'a bummer' to the children still trying to reconcile the great artist with the very mortal man.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: It's a portrait of a man who never got his full due while he lived -- and whose memory will be served well by its loving documentation.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: ...an excellent introduction to [Townes] Van Zandt's life and music.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: An unnarrated collection of gently told reminiscences that rove impressionistically, the film touches on various points in a career that remained a well-kept secret from the start, when Van Zandt began performing in the late 1960s.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Vivid yet impressionistic, Margaret Brown's film tribute to the singer-songwriter Townes Van Zandt brings the late musician and his career into rare focus.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Unlike many music documentaries, this is not a drab, talking-heads affair but a portrait assembled from evocative images and songs.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: A sobering but compassionate look at a man who ultimately might have been even more troubled than gifted.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Brown weaves together audio footage and taped interviews that show a man whose proximity to death had calcified into a sharp blade of self-deprecating wit.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: ...required viewing for Van Zandt fans, probably required for country music fans, and even of interest to those with no great affection for either.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Rather than connecting all the chronological dots, Brown has fashioned Van Zandt's balm-to-the- brokenhearted legacy into potent cinematic poetry.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: A less-than-satisfying examination of the country singer's art, career and demons.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Manages a pretty fair portrait of Van Zandt and his personal demons, pressures and joys.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: A documentary that in its spirit and feel catches some of the vulnerability and naive optimism of its subject, Van Zandt.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Van Zandt comes across as humble, witty, empathetic, sympathetic and very, very gifted.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: [An] honest, sobering and poignant tribute to a tortured talent who died young and left behind a treasure chest of songs.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: He may not have been a good guy, but fellow musicians tend to focus on his work and they can't say enough good things about his talent. They sing his praises and sing his songs.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Van Zandt gets his own documentary
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Loving but unflinching documentary on celebrated singer and songwriter Townes Van Zandt.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: While the film lacks polish, there's enough good material and good performances to keep everything on track.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: A surprisingly deep understanding of an otherwise obscure artist.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: This may not be a solid biography, but it feels true.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: A textured, elegiac, and deeply plangent music documentary. Brown's film, never exposing Van Zandt to too much harsh light, preserves this enigma just enough that it makes you want to go back to the music after you've caught these glimpses of the man.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: The film feels most authentic when it talks about the exhilaration and the freedom Van Zandt and other musicians feel when they cut off ties to family and home to make a songwriter's life on the road.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: Best of all, there is beautifully preserved in-concert footage, particularly a 1995 Amsterdam gig...
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt

review_content: A scrupulously well-researched documentary about one of early cinema's greatest pioneers and the world's first woman filmmaker.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Yes, Green interviews important scholars and archivists...but their voices are drowned out by people with no ties to film history who all express amazement that they've never heard of Guy-Blaché.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: What starts as a biography turns into a detective thriller as Green crisscrosses the globe, searching for clues as to why Guy-Blaché has been forgotten.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: In her passionate debut film, Green achieves a feat of making a two-level research project informative and entertaining. Exciting and essential documentary for film history!
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: When we talk about cinema, we talk about the history of cinema. It's an incomplete history; it always has been and always will be. But, thanks to Be Natural, we can start to see what the whole picture looks like. What a beautiful picture it is.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché is essential viewing for those who want a complete perspective on the history of film.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: An important contribution to making sure no one ever again asks "Who?" at the mention of Alice Guy-Blaché.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Not only a portrait of the woman who made more than a thousand of the very first films, but a mystery detective story about how the achievements of a trailblazing woman were erased, and found again.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: ...nobody can leave Be Natural without wanting to see more of Guy-Blaché's work.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Dazzling -- one of the seminal documentaries on early film history and must-see movie watching for any serious cinephile.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: A woman way ahead of her time and a reminder that Hollywood lessens itself by not allowing women to be judged on their talents rather than their willingness to be abused.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: I can't begin to express the impact Be Natural had on me. I knew of Alice Guy-Blaché but had only a nodding acquaintance with her work. I am grateful to Pamela Green for opening my eyes. This is a revelatory film
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: The breadth of detail about not just film and Guy-Blaché's body of work but also the actual process of how a woman's work gets erased is jaw-dropping, and Be Natural has the potential to completely upend the canon of international cinema.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: This film is so overdue, yet it couldn't have come at a more perfect time. As more people are championing gender parity in cinema, this film would likely inspire to keep up the good fight. I can't recommend this film enough to anyone.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: An essential watch for cinephiles and beyond, letBe Natural bethe first step in your discovery of a talented artist
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: By the end of "Be Natural," you won't only have a clear idea of who this remarkable woman was; you may well have acquired a new taste in old movies.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché works hard to carve her name in the firmament, making an expansive argument for her as a pioneer in technique, a varied and gifted artist, and a shrewd businesswoman.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: With copious biographical details, a plethora of interviews and a multitude of ... on-screen animated illustrations ... the director walks us through Guy-Blaché's accomplishments.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché is another step towards correctly affirming Guy-Blaché in the pantheon of the world's greatest directors, but it is a far throw from what the titular story actually deserves.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Thank goodness "Be Natural" is here to set a brilliant, distinguished, invaluable record straight.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché does a great service in making sure that we never again forget about Guy-Blaché's contributions to film history, even if the film itself doesn't equal the greatness of its subject.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Director Pamela B. Green makes film history a pleasure to watch and a gateway for those who would otherwise pass on the chance to explore moviemaking before the advent of sound.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Pamela B. Green's documentary operates as an archival treasure hunt as well as a tribute to film preservation the world over.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Thoughtful and dedicated to the mission of history and the contrasting of then to now. An absolutely stunning chronicle.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: One of Green's masterstrokes is the way she structures her film like a great filmic treasure hunt. The truth, though, is that it itself is the treasure.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: A vital effort to right past wrongs and fix the messes made by (mostly) men.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: This film is packed with priceless old films and informative interviews. Alice's films were so ahead of her time in themes and technique that it boggles the mind why we didn't know her name until now. Green's research and presentation are impressive.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: [Be Natural] injects the similar sort of vigour and verve into her story that her own films would have elicited in audiences. It's a delight of a documentary and one that will, as its title suggests, reveal untold treasures to its audience.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: While 'Be Natural' is foremost a celebration of the critical work of a pioneer, it also poses some uncomfortable questions. Who writes the history of cinema?
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: A frustrating story, but also an exhilarating one, in that Guy-Blaché's work is deserving and we're finally finding out about it.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: More than a new chapter in cinematic history, Green's film becomes a key piece towards revising everything we thought we knew.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Directed by Pamela B. Green, this documentary is at once a love letter to and a furious argument for the lasting legacy and inarguable genius of Guy-Blaché.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: An impactful mystery, filmmaker Pamela B. Green's debut is a gift to film historians and an educational treat for anyone interested in how the art form was born.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Filmmaker Pamela B. Green has an obvious passion for her subject and did an amazing job uncovering new material about Alice Guy Blaché. Yet the film itself suffers from some serious flaws.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Digging in the style of an investigative reporter, Green creates a portrait of this pioneer in both her highly-paid success and later unhappiness... Happily, Green's intrepid research restores Guy-Blache to her rightful place in cinema history.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Thankfully, Be Natural offers an opportunity to pull [Alice Guy-Blaché] out of the shadows and back into the light, where future filmmakers and historians can appreciate all that [she] created, paving the way for generations to come.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Do you know Alice Guy-Blaché? Documentarian Pamela B. Green thinks you should. She is clearly right.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: If you come into the film knowing absolutely nothing about Guy-Blache, the film will serve as both a genuine revelation about the early days of filmmaking and a fascinating real-life mystery.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Alice Guy-Blaché produced, wrote or directed more than 1,000 films... But why was she forgotten? Pamela B. Green's doc piles on detail after detail after detail, equal parts detective story, biography and agreeable hagiography.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: The term "essential documentary," often overused, finds true ground here with Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: a profoundly important and enlightening documentary on an early filmmaking pioneer that time threatened to forget.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: ...an interesting, frequently engaging look at a largely forgotten filmmaker whose influence and precedent setting far outweighed her notoriety.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Cinephiles will be in heaven , but Be Natural is also an astounding story of how the very first woman director had her life's work wiped off Hollywood's map. It is also a great detective story about how she has been rediscovered.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: This makes a great companion piece to the "Gaumont Treasures: 1897-1913," a meticulously restored DVD collection that contains a good number of the director's films.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: This movie is absolutely fantastic and I almost ignored it. Don't live your life without knowing of Alice Guy-Blache, watch this flick!
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Alice Guy-Blache' has a legacy that should be celebrated NOT silenced. Fascinated how Ancestry.com aided filmmaker Pamela Green in unfolding the mystery of Blache's groundbreaking legacy and techniques. Excellent filmmaking!
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Part engaging history lesson and part riveting detective story, the goal of Green's movie is to correct the historical record and declare that, after more than a century, a cultural and creative pioneer has earned her time in the spotlight.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Thanks in large part to Pamela B. Green's lovely and loving film, Alice Guy-Blaché is no longer behind the scenes. She is front and center, exactly where she should have been for the past century.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Hopefully the flashy result will encourage at least some young cineastes to look at more of Guy-Blaché's work.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Alice might not have set out to make history, but she sure as hell didn't deserve to be forgotten by it.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: [A] documentary that more than makes the case for Alice.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Be Natural is an essential film to appreciate cinema and the role that women played in its development-as well as the possibilities for female directors today and tomorrow.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: The film is a must for aficionados.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: A remarkable documentary about a remarkable woman...[Director Pamela] Green re-assembles her life with deep respect and a palpable love for an artist who bypassed the dictates of convention and rewrote the rules to suit herself.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: ...a lively film that incorporates archival materials, contemporary interviews, film clips, animation, and narration by Jodie Foster.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: not just a biographical documentary, but a compelling drama about how history is written and how easily its major players can be erased when they don't fit into the convenient, dominant narrative
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Alice Guy-Blaché was a consummate artist, and Pamela B. Green is gloriously following in her revolutionary footsteps.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: The all-important films are shown in almost subliminal excerpts, offering today's audiences little opportunity to assess the place of this remarkable woman in cinema history.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: What a wonderful experience it is to be taken on Pamela B. Green's tenacious journey to uncover the story of the first female director, screenwriter, producer and studio owner!
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: What I like about it especially is that it captures this fleeting moment of almost innocence near the time of the dawn of cinema when directing was not automatically assumed to be a man's job and where women directing a film was no big deal.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: I think this is a fascinating story, although it's only an interesting account of it...The interviews they found with her are fascinating. She's charming, she's articulate, she's witty, and you wish there were more of them.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: A vital, deeply moving documentary that at long last acknowledges Guy-Blaché's invaluable gift to cinema, insuring that this long-forgotten pioneer will finally be given her due.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: [An] enlightening documentary, which is highly recommended to any cinephile.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Have you ever heard of Director Alice Guy-Blaché? You probably haven't - and the reason isn't a huge surprise: THE PATRIARCHY. Thankfully Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché, Directed by Pamela B. Green, is here to illuminate all of us.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: "Be Natural" uncovers one of the movie greats and gives her the justice and spotlight she deserves.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Be Natural occasionally wanders, but in the end it offers a passionate portrait of a remarkable woman, a necessary historical corrective and an urgent argument for the importance of film preservation.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: [Pamela] Green has created a crucial piece of the puzzle of the origin of cinema as we know it and a seminal documentary on film history.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: The illuminating documentary -a must-see for serious cinephiles- delivers a cascade of information and insight in a clear and dynamic manner. [Full review in Spanish]
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: ...illustrates how Alice Guy-Blaché, thought to be the first female director, fell through the cracks of history, and makes a case for Guy-Blaché's place among the titans of early cinema.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché lays out the facts of Guy-Blaché's life and provides enough samples from her 22-year career to demonstrate that she was an essential film pioneer.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: If you're planning on working in the industry in any capacity, it's probably for the best that you learn about Guy-Blaché. Now that the documentary is out, you have no excuse not to know about the woman who launched the film industry as we know it.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: It definitely piques your interest about her work.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Sometimes real life narratives are every bit as fantastic as the stories we tell.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Be Natural delightfully unearths a female film pioneer forgotten by history.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: The ingrained sexism it highlights could form the basis of several sequels.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: A playful but ardent documentary tribute to Guy Blaché, a film-maker fully deserving the overworked title of pioneer.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: [A] hectic, garrulous, fascinating documentary...
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: [The full story] of the creative contributions of women to the film industry in its early decades is still fighting for a place in mainstream awareness. The informative -- and emotionally involving -- Be Natural is a valuable battering ram in that fight.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Cineastes, film nerds and feminists alike will be gripped by this documentary portrait of Alice Guy-Blaché. Who? That's the point.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: The film's exhaustive investigation into her life and legacy uncovers plenty of maddening instances of sexism... but it also highlights the concerted efforts of archivists and historians to start setting the record straight.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Green succeeded in creating a beautiful, neat tapestry, weaving together the loose threads left behind by Guy-Blaché, helping to reinstate her in the history of cinema.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: By the end of this two-hour impeccably researched and well-curated production, you will not only learn of Guy-Blache's well-rounded oeuvre that tackles a varied array of genres... But your very notion of what silent films are like might be elevated.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: Newly-discovered footage of Guy-Blaché films and the subject herself, including rare audio recordings and a restored video interview enrich her portrait...
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: It's the awkward editing, superfluous celebrity interviews, and an emphasis on the search for inconsequential facts that obscure what should be its focus - Guy-Blaché's formidable talent.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: We can see comedy, social drama, even a few westerns in there...her name should never, ever be forgotten again.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: This frustrating and exhilarating documentary is mandatory viewing for any cinephile.
movie_title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

review_content: [The film] gives the seminal early '90s hip-hop group as stylish and intimate a treatment as fans could hope for, paying as much attention to the music in question as it does to the characters who made it.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Starts out rather conventionally and builds into one of the most engaging music docs in years.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Seminal hip-hop act gets due praise in solid bio-doc.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Even as an "18 months later" epilogue ensures us that everything's hunky dory, this is one surprisingly grim celebration of a group Rapaport obviously loves.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: While indulging in plenty of back-in-the-day remembrances, the film also creates a vivid image of the hip-hop that [A Tribe Called Quest] loved and also couldn't wait to subvert.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Director Rapaport captures these intimate dynamics with startling depth, and the band members provide candid interviews that are amazing in their honesty and emotional insight.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: A welcome blast of '90s nostalgia, taking us back to a time - and a sound - that pulsates with optimism.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: ...is a galvanizing documentary capable of sending audience members out on personal musical quests of their own.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: A phenomenal documentary.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: You'll definitely leave the movie hoping [A Tribe Called Quest] will work out their differences to make more music together sometime in the future.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: As an introduction to A Tribe Called Quest and a history of a very particular side of hip-hop, this is pretty hard to beat.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Rapaport deserves credit for making a movie that's neither exploitative nor puffy, and in which we find ourselves rooting for these two friends to get over themselves and work things out.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: But unlike so many movies about the rise and fall of successful bands, this one manages to capture the thrill of discovery that A Tribe Called Quest enjoyed, at least in their early years.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: The film serves both as a welcome document and reminder of the group in its prime, while also creating a portrait of lives still in motion, grown men trying to move on from yet respect the work of their younger selves.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: it's Rapaport's mistake to spend so much time and energy unpacking something so much more obvious, and so much less interesting, than Tribe's music.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Rapaport, a longtime Quest fan, clearly admires Tip. He's just too forthright a storyteller to bury the tale of the quartet's acrimonious unraveling.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: A hip-hop version of The Rolling Stones' 'Gimme Shelter' and one of the best music docs to come out in recent years. Whether you love hip hop or not, this is a documentary not to be missed and one that will not be forgotten.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Even those who never joined the cult of A Tribe Called Quest will find this clear-eyed chronicle of their career irresistible.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Rapaport, in his feature directorial debut, does an admirable job recounting the group's formation and dissecting its dissolution.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: "Beats, Rhymes & Life" is a must for hip-hop heads. Others will either be won over or left wondering what all the fuss is about.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: A reminder, part "Behind the Music" and part something better, that even artists professing love and togetherness have a hard time keeping it going.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Rapaport smartly focuses on the yin-and-yang duo of Q-Tip and Phife Dawg, the group's lead rappers, and a fascinating study in contrasts.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Tribe's music takes a backseat to power struggle and personality conflict.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: An outstanding effort, and one of the more honest band biopics in recent years.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: An entertaining discussion backed by awesomely laid-back tracks ... Chronicles a creative, jazz-influenced scene of hip-hop heads that saw the music as the cake, not the icing.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: There is a love/hate relationship within A Tribe Called Quest
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Even as the band implodes, "Beats" flows as smoothly as Q-Tip on "Verses From the Abstract." It's the tension between the group's core members that really propels the film forward.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Either mandatory rap-nerd masturbation material or the most boring movie imaginable about that group with the song you liked in middle school.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: The band's politically charged hits still sound as fresh as when they were recorded, and their side projects may have improved with age. I had to download Jungle Brothers' "Black Is Black" the minute I left the theater.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: The emotional honesty Rapaport captures on screen comes off as real, a cut above standard-issue Behind the Music drama in terms of believability.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Somewhat against the odds, Rapaport manages to parlay his access and sycophancy into the plaint of a concerned fan: Please, fellas, squash this.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: A surprisingly concise and eloquent look at hip-hop itself, abetted by analytical contributions from some of the genre's most popular artists.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: I approached "Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of A Tribe Called Quest" with a music lover's curiosity and a film lover's fondness for documentaries. I was not disappointed on either count.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: There are scenes toward the end of the movie that hint at a fuzzier tomorrow for Tribe, but you leave appreciating the music as it was, not hoping for anything else.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: It's a doozy.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: The movie gets the beats and rhymes down pat, but the life part is a little messy. Oh well, two out of three ain't bad.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: There's nothing new about the bickering between lead rappers Q-Tip and Phife, or their redundant breakup-and-reunion cycle. It helps that these lyricists are our key narrators, so at least they add wit and humour to their brief history.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Good vibes propel what is a fairly straightforward account of the band's formation, album output, and acrimonious breakup.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: It tells a real story that is both complex and coherent, putting ATCQ's impact on the level of what Dylan and The Beatles provided in their respective moments in musical history. And the argument is well made.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: If you want to know what hip-hop is all about, this 'rapumentary' is a fine place to start.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Even if you think you don't like hip-hop you may find yourself captivated by the musicality of A Tribe Called Quest, and that alone is reason to watch this documentary...
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Respectful but not idolatrous, this is one 'Behind the Music' piece that even those who have never heard of the group can appreciate.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Thanks to a particularly even-handed job by director Michael Rapaport, the story emerges as compelling, even for non-fans in the audience.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Despite accusations of nearly succumbing to spotlighting beefs over beats, the film comes off as an honest representation of a great group that's not to be forgotten.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: A combination of timing, access, a visual aesthetic that reflects ATCQ's Afrocentric "surface philosophy" (as the crew's look is described) and, most importantly, story-conscious editing elevates the doc above the norm.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Rapaport gets at the dynamics of a group that struggles even now to get along well enough to get paid - again.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: That mood of musical unity, of a sonic movement, is incredible, vibrantly recounted in Beats. It's more than just a documentary, it's a time capsule of hip hop originality and confidence.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: The movie's value is in informing and illuminating, not provoking.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: It's difficult to get a grasp on just what audience this documentary is made for.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: An adoring, though enlightening, look at the tumultuous run of the influential hip-hop group.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: This documentary therefore did exactly what a good music doco should do: brought people like me up to speed and, according to reports from more serious hip hop fans in the audience, provided lots of information that wasn't previously well known.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Maybe I'm just a sucker for good old fashioned hip-hop, but I found Michael Rapaport's totally-by-the-numbers music doco [Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of A Tribe Called Quest] absolutely compelling.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Warning: The bassline Ron Carter contrived for the classic cut 'Buggin' Out' is about as easy to dislodge from your brain as a 'Night Gallery' earwig.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: This authorized documentary is more of a celebration of the legendary Queens quartet than a serious exploration of their art. But considering how brilliant they were at their peak, it's hard to disagree with the general sentiment.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Rapaport, clearly a fan, is able to capture both the ongoing love and the tension within the band.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Rappaport covers a huge spectrum of voices and opinions, and the themes he explores get into personal relationships -- something everyone can relate to.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: While it's uncertain if A Tribe Called Quest will ever get back together and play again, it's quite certain fans will love and appreciate BEATS, RHYMES & LIFE: THE TRAVELS OF A TRIBE CALLED QUEST as their final encore.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: [I]t might have been nice if the documentary had worked a bit harder to find a real internal narrative.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: It shows with close detail the inner troubles of one of the most influential groups in modern hip-hop, and how they all work and strive to remain an important part of that genre's future.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest

review_content: Perhaps it's time we acknowledged that, despite their outr appetites, Warhol's superstars may have been legitimately boring people.
Polite but poorly structured.
The film isn't blinded by Candy's beauty and celebrity; it digs critically, if still empathetically, beneath.
An extraordinarily sad, touching and compassionate documentary...
A sad, lyrical reflection on the foolish worship of movie stars.
This riveting documentary about one of the legendary triumphant gender illusionists is also a compelling portrait of an endlessly fascinating era.
A fairly besotted look, produced under the guidance of a longtime friend.
"Beautiful Darling" makes extensive use of photos, sketches and Darling's diaries belonging to Jeremiah Newton, a gay pal she lived with on and off until her death from cancer in 1974.
A discomforting look at a transsexual actress's difficult life and isolating pursuit of fame.
"Beautiful Darling" is sympathetic and critical, a sobering reminder in this fame-grabbing age of a time when gender politics, art and artifice could make for a turbulent identity cocktail.
Eventually, everybody who ever spent five minutes with Andy Warhol will have a film made about them
Like fellow Factory figures Edie Sedgwick and Jackie Curtis, Darling now gets her own documentary, and proves a more than worthy subject.
Darling's fragility was no secret, which gives even the movie's comical moments an underlying poignancy.
...suffers from an egregiously "inside" sensibility that ensures neophytes will periodically be left scratching their heads at the whole thing.
A celebration of Peter Pan-like spirits who felt the freedom to express themselves before anybody cared.
Aaron Rose and Joshua Leonard don't properly contextualize this mini-scene within the larger art world, nor provide basic background on their speakers.
Regardless of Rose's intentions, his underachieving airiness is both entertaining and perfectly fitting for the slacker ennui of his clique's rising years.

The cultural time capsule doubles as a testament to the joys of outsiders bonding, with interviewees emphasizing how they finally felt like they belonged somewhere after years of asphyxiating alone on the fringe.
a celebration of rude and raw art and the kinetic charge of experiencing something fresh and undefiled
Pleasing though less-than-profound homage.
A product of the movement as much as an ode to it, the film is a gem because of the immaturity and intimacy that it shares with those featured in it.
[An] alternately winsome and irritating documentary about the art scene that grew out of the Alleged Gallery on Manhattan's Lower East Side in the 1990s.
Some of the art is probably interesting, but Rose's own video-influenced filmmaking style leaves little time for inspection or reflection.
[A] pleasant film, which sings the praises of nonconformity.
Though [Director] Mr. Rose can't be blamed for waxing nostalgic, he can't much expect us to care about so fawning and self-serving a document.
It succeeds intermittently and is reasonably enlightening, but whether audiences are really going to warm up to the individuals presented here is questionable.
An absorbing look at how a circle of dispossessed young artists from the 1990s eventually found its way to mainstream success.
This is a pleasant enough visual romp with surprisingly few down notes.
The film's score, by Money Mark, is an entertainment in itself.
One of the year's best documentaries.
That said, all art deserves biography, and great art deserves recognition.
On your deathbed you will want back the time it takes to see this one.

An amiable portrait of the artist as a scruffy slacker, and a useful jumping off point for anyone interested in investigating some of the cultural issues that marked the 1990s and the start of the new millennium.
Like the art scene it documents, Beautiful Losers is chaotic, anarchic, rambling and populated by charismatic freaks with statement T-shirts, complicated haircuts and impossibly rare trainers.
You can't help but feel like a bit of an eye-rolling parent, wondering if a few of them might benefit from a proper job and a light slap.
The affection these people have for each other is what makes Beautiful Losers (the name is taken from one of their shows) so attractive.
Prioritising the self over the job means Beautiful Losers is rarely more than a compendium of loveliness and apology.
As you watch the movie wholeheartedly and uncritically celebrate the group's "nonconformist" ethos (shouldn't someone gently break it to them?), you can feel the energy being sucked out of you.
A shamelessly self-promoting homage documentary to a like-minded group of rebel pop culture artists, who work together in a NYC collective but do independent work.
The whole ethos portrayed in this film seems to be of a tightly knit group, referencing and re-referencing each other ad infinitum.
Quack or saint? Dr. Gerson, whose work in allegedly curing cancer by alternative means, is highlighted in a light, even convincing way.
The end result not only constitutes an uncomfortable--dare I say, inorganic--collusion of fact and fiction but also suggests we're being indoctrinated into a cult.

The director's suggestion that big pharmaceutical companies have no interest in actually curing cancer is credible, but the film itself unfortunately makes Kroschel's beliefs come off like just so much hippie propaganda.

While docu's claims and criticism yield nothing especially new, the form of their exposition seems singularly ingenious, stylistically falling somewhere between a 1950s educational film and some sort of Norman Rockwellian infomercial.

Kroschel positions The Beautiful Truth as a sort of instructional video for young people on the merits of eating healthy, but its creepy messianic vibe is far more toxic than all the pollutants in all the processed food you could ever consume.
The picture carries an element of nostalgia and yet thunders down too hard with a lot of one-sided perspectives.
The Beautiful Truth is a documentary about contemporary health hazards and alternative treatments.
There may be truth in what Kroschel says, but you won't find it in this pedantic film, which has all the veracity of a late-night TV infomercial.
An unusual and sobering documentary which turns conventional wisdom about health matters on its head.
Boring like a one-note school lecture but nevertheless is credible as it makes its case about the need for alternative medicines.

A powerful documentary that offers both a chilling expose of the toxins in our food that are causing so much disease and an affirmation of a plant-oriented therapy that has cured cancer in many individuals.
Comes off mostly like a hybrid of retro-style educational film and late-night infomercial.
[A] condescending, manipulative film.
It's Michael Moore without the truculence, PBS without the pretension, CNN without the commercial grandstanding.
Caveat emptor really applies here, because your health is at stake. Do your research, do your homework, and use common sense.

The film cannot help but be described as colorful just based on the visualizations of White's work alone, but his persona matches his creations as he tries to prove that art does not have to be uber-serious and can just be fun.
Once the film starts showing behind the scenes footage of Pee-Wee's Playhouse there's more of a point of interest. And it keeps going very well from there.
Beauty is Embarrassing is masterfully directed by Neil Berkeley.
White's philosophy of life seems to be "Just do it," and that's what he's been doing more or less his whole life.
Painter Wayne White emerges as an unsung force of nature in Neil Berkeley's zippy, delightful Beauty is Embarrassing.
An explosively realized reminder of the purity of craft and the need to support such efforts with a meaty personality and unique vision.
Beauty is Embarrassing is one of the greatest examples of a career celebration ever.
Neil Berkeley's doc is as puckish as its subject, so steeped in artist Wayne White's creative juices that it makes you want to go straight home and start making things.
A vivid, fluorescent-colored portrait of a sane man possessed with insane creativity.
This exuberant documentary's most affecting message concerns a timelessly profound verity: the value of roots, humor, family and old friends.
Those with a high tolerance for the ultimate four-letter word, and a love for eccentrics, will be entertained by both White and his art.
A buoyant, engaging, visually alluring portrait of the Tennessee-born White ...
Though the movie isn't wildly original, its time-tested, artistic mantra of "just go out there and do it" is hard to resist.
The doc meanders occasionally, but we're grateful when it comes back to White and his creations.
An embraceable tale of childhood mischief, teenage rebellion, award-winning creativity and enduring imagination.
His art is a force that can't be contained: No wonder he felt so at home in the warped environs of Pee-wee's Playhouse.
Beauty is Embarrassing is a funny, enormously entertaining film, built around an autobiographical show White performs for a theater audience.

These moments elevate Beauty Is Embarrassing beyond mere tribute to an undersung artist into a far rarer thing: a glimpse into the galvanizing effect art -- good art, bad art, fine art, folk art, or 5th-grader art -- can have.
It remains a story at all times - there's a moment at a book signing that will give you a big smile and goosebumps - and it keeps throwing great things to look at up on the screen.
This isn't necessarily a life-altering work, but there's no denying that the fun White gets out of his work is pretty irresistible.
An amiable if not especially urgent celebration of the life and work of Wayne White.
It's ... indulgent, not admitting that White's new gimmick wears out its welcome, and never making the case that White deserves his own documentary.
Using animation, CGI and stop-motion, and mixing analog and digital video, director Berkeley transforms 'Beauty Is Embarrassing' into a White-inspired but Berkeley made work of pop-folk art
Neil Berkeley's infectiously affectionate portrait of artist, puppeteer and genially profane provocateur Wayne White.
If for no other reason, the film should at least be seen for its visuals -- or, rather, for White's visuals.
"Beauty Is Embarrassing" is an undeniably likable film, mainly because White is a likable guy who believes comedy is at least as important as tragedy.
Judging from this documentary, his character is as exuberant as his work, and he seems to be one of those lucky people who simply can't stop creating...
This is certainly not to suggest that White's work is worthless or unimpressive, but the way it is sold to us is predictable and unclever.
And so [Wayne] White continues to be his own man, as it's clear from this well-crafted documentary that he always has been.
An affectionate portrait of one creative man, Beauty [is Embarrassing] may make you wonder how many other artists like [Wayne] White have stories just as deserving of a cinematic telling.
This documentary shows a woman trying to do good in the world - and who still believes that good can be done.
I bet there wasn't a dry eye in the house.
Becoming is very much a work in progress and hence, good TV across the spectrum.
Certainly "Becoming" will please her supporters and tick off her detractors. But not much more.
I have no doubt that there is a large and eager audience for this kind of no-warts-at-all look at the family, but to pretend that it is anything other than a commercial is a fantasy.

Michelle Obama's story is her story and she tells it well, peppering in the lessons that structure the book - usually messages about embracing her background, finding her voice and the responsibility to use this platform that she never wanted.
Being a controlled look doesn't make it less honest or impactful, it's just honest in a different way that doesn't involve showing her husband and daughters eating breakfast in pajamas.
Set your expectations accordingly, and you'll... get a lot out of "Becoming."
[A] watchable, but carefully authorised, behind-the-scenes documentary...
The book reflects on how she became first lady; the film suggests she's still growing as a person, empowering us to do the same.

Right in time for Mother's Day, Michelle Obama brings her inspirational, best-selling book to Netflix with a message of hope, family, learning to embrace and dare to become the best version of you possible. Love every single minute of this. Right on Time
To the extent that "Becoming" has something to sell, and it does, it's not the subject so much as what she stands for.

To her credit, Michelle Obama doesn't come across as complaining about her reality; rather, it's as if she's able to step outside herself and witness the strangeness of an existence where "the entire attention of everything is you" from a bird's-eye view.
The disjointed nature of the film does have one upside in that it hints at what might become of Obama's life now.

"Becoming" is most memorable, however, as a chronicle of Obama's interactions with the public, who stand in line for hours to get their copies of "Becoming" signed and, in turn, receive more than just a nod.

At times, it feels like an extended promotional video but there's an eloquence to the way Michelle Obama speaks to her supporters and, if anything, "Becoming" certainly showcases how and why she became a powerhouse on the campaign trail.

Becoming's most inspirational moments come when we see Obama's willingness to admit that she's struggled to find who she is, and, in turn, when we hear her urge others toward fearlessly doing the same.

Even with its flaws, Becoming is a compelling documentary, offering a carefully revealing look at a whip smart, ferociously practical woman trying to understand how her historic time in the White House changed herself, her family and the nation.
So much of Becoming revolves around the expectations the public still has of her, not only as the first black First Lady but as an Obama in the era of Trump.
Obama's multicity conversations are invigorating, offering more personal insights and showing sharper versions of her signature charm and humor.

It doesn't feel like it's laying the groundwork for a future campaign from its subject, not matter how adored it makes her look. Instead, it's more of an insistent feature-length case for the family having done, and given, enough.
It's tricky to tell a feel-good story in a time in which many people are feeling anything but good, but Becoming film insists on doing just that.
Michelle Obama has a captivating screen presence, whether it's seeing her being interviewed on her book tour, seen in quiet moments, or anything in between.
Becoming emerges as a semi-worshipful depiction of a world-famous woman in flux. She's such enjoyable and inspiring company, though, that you might not mind that.
Becoming is also a reminder of the leadership that America so badly needs in the White House.
A film about, among other things, the art of flawless surfaces - and a woman who has long had to master them.
A superhero hasn't revealed herself so refreshingly and candidly since Ruth Bader Ginsburg disrobed for RBG.
The strength of this Netflix documentary about Mrs Obama is not only that it harnesses her unmatched energy, but also that it captures the quieter, more reflective moments of her story.

[I]t's an intimate portrait of a public figure, and one of its strengths is showing how comfortable, confident, and inspiring Obama has become now that she's free to be herself instead of the wife of the leader of the free world.
Yes, the movie often feels like hagiography, but given the state of the nation, we could all use an inspiring figure like Michelle Obama, if not an actual saint.
"Becoming" is not trying to court controversy. Similar to her book, it aims to inspire young female supporters with the philosophy that "your story is your power."
Enlightening journey with Michelle Obama on her book tour.
What Becoming lacks in intimacy, it makes up for in emotional outpouring.
Guess who made it? Barack and Michelle Obama's production company. It's called, as the book was, Becoming. It turns out the title is a bit ironic.
Maybe you plan to settle in for an 89-minute feel-good experience that allows you to bask in Obama's calm dignity... If that is all you desire, "Becoming" will oblige you.

"Becoming" lets us get close to Michelle Obama while keeping its distance. It is endlessly fascinating as a chronicle of life on the road for someone who helped leave a mark on recent American history.
Becoming more or less offers Obama fanservice... But it's most interesting in the rare moments when Obama speaks candidly about topics that had been verboten, or at least strongly discouraged.
It's all perfectly grand and inspiring. But it's also everything you expect from an authorized documentary about Michelle Obama.
Though informative and competently crafted, Becoming seems to be more about warm feelings than evaluation.
The portrait of Obama in Becoming is a familiar one, but no less impactful.

We hear her before a book signing explaining the importance of eye contact and listening and empathy, but when the event begins, it's pretty clear that it all comes naturally...Becoming gives] viewers what they want...
These are the sorts of words we need to hear, and believe, right now.
Remarkably uplifting.
A missed opportunity. Disappointingly doesn't go deeper or further with its charismatic, inspiring central figure. [Full review in Spanish]
Even in cavernous, darkened arenas, Obama is a natural storyteller - candid and witty, punctuating anecdotes with perfect pause-for-applause comic timing.
A collection of "feels," hugs and tears with fans, students and family, and big promotional moments that director Nadia Hallgren wisely never allows to come off as a "victory lap."
If you loved the Obamas or even if you didn't, Becoming shows Michelle's side of the story and offers up an understanding that many of us might not have had while she was the first lady.
Hallgren pieces together a much more robust picture of Obama, one that honors where she's come from and what she's accomplished while creating a space for what's yet to come.
The intimate Netflix movie follows the former first lady on her arena book tour, recalling her past and inspiring with her grace.
A solidly-made documentary that earns high marks for substance, but very few style points....an interesting picture of how Michelle Obama achievers HER American dream.

Overall the film feels overly curated and manicured, but it's worth it just to hear a recounting of the last day in the White House, with Michelle telling her daughter and their friends, "We have to get up and go, the Trumps are coming."

Becoming does not ask difficult questions, nor does it present any new or shocking information... But it does offer a brilliant portrait of a woman who, politics aside, was and is a world icon. [Full review in Spanish]

In spite of its relative shallowness, Becoming is still well worth the watch thanks to its inspiring leading lady, beautiful music, and gripping narrative of the struggles and triumphs of being the first Black woman to serve as first lady.
The movie works efficiently as biography.
The sad, unintended moral of Becoming is that if this country never sees a President Michelle Obama, it is our own fault.
Verges on an ad for Michelle Obama's memoir, but a sincerely warm one. We glimpse a woman authentically funny, self-aware, down-to-earth. Like spending time with a friend you didn't realize you had.

This former First Lady doesn't settle any scores here, following her mantra, "When they go low, you go high." The film is well constructed so that you'll understand what it's like to be with a political rock star on a high-powered book tour.
It's a testament to her hard work as First Lady and as a private citizen that the sparkling glimpse it offers feels like more than enough.

It's a slick look at the former first lady, out of the White House and carving out her life post-politics, but it's as polished and smoothed out as a campaign ad. It's a warm latte, delivered to you in your favorite mug.
If you loved the book, then you're going to love the movie... I found myself watching the film with a big, goofy grin most of the time.
With Obama herself as narrator, it's a personal diary -- bereft of tension and short on surprises with a perpetually sunny guide treating you to an intimate but selective tour of her life so far.
The frustrating part of this documentary is it is so safe!
This slickly produced companion piece to Michelle Obama's 2018 memoir takes you inside her rock-star world, with an asterisk.
So why watch Becoming? For the simple reason that her life story resounds with hope for a better tomorrow, which starts by telling one's story.
Scrape away the gush and the swaggy fashion, and a fascinating portrait emerged of a rather unhappy and discontented high achiever.
"Becoming" is still a quietly informative, uplifting film.

Watching a young black girl, giddy as she imitates the former First Lady's walk down a hall, we get the sense that the mere experience of being in the same space as Obama will change some of these girls forever. They light up the screen.
You feel a connection with Michelle Obama. She reminds us that you don't have to be the loudest one in the room or even the nastiest one to be heard. It's what we need to hear right now.
Michelle told her story with charm, grit, adventurism and several appalling book-tour choices of dress.
If you're looking for something to watch to make you feel like the world will get better and that there's hope, watch Becoming.
Becoming is educational, encouraging -- and becoming in every sense of the word.
It's definitely the most intimate portrait of Michelle Obama we've seen committed to film.

The movie hits some very familiar beats that are often seen in tour documentaries. There's a 'feel-good home movie' approach to the documentary, as opposed to a 'journalistic exposé' approach. Some people will have a problem with that, while others won't.

I don't think Jack ever got it. He remains cynical when working with real children. He makes jokes at the expense of babbling incomprehensible kids. Look, we know it makes no sense, but you don't have to joke about it with their parents.

This is a more honest (and certainly less hokey) manifestation of a true Christmas story; the kind that should be added to the spate of annual holiday fare. Like perhaps on a double bill with Rare Exports: A Christmas Tale.
Surprisingly hilarious without being too mocking nor too cute.
It's charming, informative, and, best of all, really funny.
The film presents interesting historical information with a great Christmas-y soundtrack, making for a somewhat enjoyable watch.
It works as a reminder of the important interactiveness of the performing arts, of actors evoking the drama, action, and emotion that computers and machines cannot.
[It] may not be fully satisfying as a documentary. But it has what any good movie needs: a star - the ever-game soprano Natalie Dessay.
Time with Dessay is worth treasuring, even when she's not singing.
Those unfamiliar with Verdi's tragedy won't understand why this production was significant, nor see much of the fruits of such hard work ...
Initially engaging, but increasingly tedious and boring. Strictly for opera aficionados.
Doc offers impressive singing and insights into opera's nonmusical dramatic challenges.
A treat for fans of opera, the performing arts and documentaries about process.

Dessay's waifishness makes her entirely believable as a woman dying from a lung disease. And the camera adores her. When her voice goes, she could have the career in movies that once seemed to await Maria Callas.
A clumsy and sadly missed opportunity to capture the creation of a great opera role by a great singer.
Sivadier and Dessay take the familiar and make it tragic once more.
Zeroing in on the art of rehearsal, "Becoming Traviata" is an exquisitely observed look at performance and the creative process.
You can follow the story even if you're unfamiliar with the opera - though a five-minute brush-up on the plot wouldn't hurt.
Bziat arranges an interesting mosaic, moving the opera's narrative forward along the same timeline as the ever-evolving, multi-faceted collaboration.

The movie is most enjoyable as a simple record of the performers, allowing one to eavesdrop on soprano Natalie Dessay and tenor Charles Castronovo as opera director Jean-Francois Sivadier coaches them through some of the libretto's more layered moments.
Watching Dessay work as a real human being and not a glittering vocal princess is a fascinating treat.
Becoming Traviata gives a compelling and rare insight into the daily life of the opera industry from the perspective of a filmmaker.

Providing an inspiration for active retirement, the ex-Harlem Renaissance chorus girls profiled in docu Been Rich All My Life are still shaking booty while most of their contemporaries can only shuffle their walkers.

Heather Lyn MacDonald's TV-grade documentary, a familiar mix of taking-head interviews and archival material, documents the Silver Belles' determination to stay on their feet but is awfully reticent when it comes to race.
The Silver Belles, five former Harlem chorus girls who are still bustin' a move despite their advanced ages, are the best kind of company there is.
They're frank, funny, resilient and altogether captivating.

Been Rich All My Life, an admiring portrait of the Silver Belles, a troupe of veteran Harlem tap dancers between the ages of 84 and 96, is a valuable historical document and a useful how-to movie about making the most of old age.

While it's enjoyable on it's own terms, there's really no reason to go all the way to the film forum and plunk down twelve bucks to see this thing, when you could probably see it on public TV in a year or two.
Been Rich All My Life has a soft, golden glow, but it could have been much richer.
These women deserve some fond acclaim for their attempts to conquer age.
Under director Heather Lyn MacDonald, the film is generic and uninspired, better suited to public TV than the big screen.

Though the stripped-down style of Heather Lyn MacDonald's documentary doesn't quite do justice to her fabulous heroines, the extraordinary energy of the five former chorus girls she profiles provides plenty of fuel.
What's onscreen comes across as little more than home-movie footage of old acquaintances getting together now and again.
Five African-American women dancers strut their stuff and revel in their camaraderie and fulfilling careers doing what they love best.
A treasure that celebrates remarkable women with a unparalleled zest for life.
Good times and bum times, they've seen it all and they're still here. Lucky us.
A richly uplifting if somewhat rambling portrait of indomitableness in the face of old age and infirmity, Been Rich All My Life will be inspirational to young and old alike.
The film could be more adept and probing, but the ladies -- Cleo Hayes, Marion Coles, Elaine Ellis, Fay Ray, and Geri Kennedy -- are delightful.
This is a sweet documentary about a small group of women who've danced their way through life.

If you only watched the first half of Been Rich All My Life, you might walk away thinking it's a so-so documentary about another fascinating, underreported piece of Harlem history. And you'd be at least half right in that assessment.
Reminds us that every life contains many acts worth hearing about, not just a select few.
