If you're not a fan now, these 105 celebratory minutes could go a long way toward your conversion.
A must-see for avid fans and a welcome primer for nascent hip-shakers everywhere.
You come away with more appreciation of how inclusive Latin jazz, with its roots in Africa, really is.
The film will greatly appeal to current fans of the musical genre and should win over more than a few converts.
A loving Buena Vista Social Club -style hymn to the rhythm and life of salsa.
A brilliantly conceived and elegantly realized documentary tribute to Latin jazz, it packs more drama into each of its 12 musical tableaux than most feature films manage in two hours.
This is one summer movie with real sizzle.
The moving moments in Calle 54 are isolated, mainly because Trueba's approach, while ensuring a killer soundtrack, is too scattershot to satisfy.
Descriptions of great art are, of course, ultimately irrelevant, and Trueba knew we'd have to experience his passion for ourselves. He's offering a dazzling invitation -- take him up on it.
Lacking the narrative didacticism of a documentary, Calle 54 functions more as Trueba's celluloid top-ten list of favorite Afro-Cuban musicians, captured lovingly in warmly-lit studio performances.
Music and movies are two of the great international languages, something Fernando Trueba's Calle 54 proves with wide smiles and an irresistible beat.
Trueba loves Latino jazz and this inspiring musical documentary beautifully reflects his appreciation and wonder.
This is one of the most infectiously joyous celebrations of musicmaking ever committed to film. See it and be ennobled.
It's precisely what a Latin jazz aficionado would want, and what would lead a novice to an affection for the genre.
What makes Calle 54 great is precisely what's missing from the other. Trueba shows us the creative act of playing music, not just a bunch of famous folks performing.
Lacks history, background and cultural roots, but it's undeniably infectious.
Even casual listeners will have a hard time not enjoying the often complex sounding and clearly infectious music.
It is easy to imagine Calle 54 having a long shelf life on home video after its run in theaters. It can be played over and over again with increasing satisfaction.
A good listen without being a particularly good watch.
See Calle 54 and your life -- at least for a couple of hours (more if you pick up the soundtrack) -- will be enriched, if only for the bounce in your step.
The knowledge of the musicians' connection to one another makes it the most touching interlude in an overlong but nevertheless entertaining film.
Anyone seeing this happily contagious film will just have to have a copy.
If the list of names in paragraph three means something to you, then Calle 54 is absolutely worth the price of admission. If you recognized no one but Tito Puente, Calle 54 probably isn't for you.
There's not been a more infectious jazz performance screen treat since 1959's classic Jazz on a Summer's Day.
The sound is terrific, the rhythms infectious and the artistic passions palpable. We wager that you'll leave this one looking for the nearest place to nab the soundtrack.
Although it isn't the human-interest story that Buena Vista Social Club was, Fernando Trueba's Calle 54 is the next best thing to that milestone musical documentary.
A nice enough appreciation of some fine musicians, but it could have been much more.
The moments are there. They sneak up on you.
Calle 54 is an engaging sampler of Latin jazz and its permutations.
This is one fan's valentine to the music he loves. It just happens that the fan is a terrific filmmaker and the music loves him back.
Collectively, the numbers add up to a triumph of ecstatic mood swinging.
It is simply awe-inspiring to watch some of these musicians, to see their passion and energy.
As much a thrill to watch as it is to listen to, a rare combination for a concert film.
The music at times seems to hover above its roots and appears detached from the characters ... creating it.
An audio-visual delight of a documentary.
There is much to be said for a music film that seems to be playing directly to us, the viewers.
For much of its 105 minutes, it simply sizzles with sophisticated passion.
Calle 54 could make you feel hot, nostalgic and possessive about this music.
A festive experience for those who are willing to embrace Latin jazz, but it doesn't reveal anything beyond a peek at a two hour celluloid concert in session.
You can find half a dozen things to complain about and yet enjoy every minute of the film completely.
Clearly a labor of love, Fernando Trueba's docu is a great chronicle of Latiz jazz, its history, performers, and enduring appeal.
Berman's failure to fully explore his colorful cast would be forgivable if that main narrative were clearer. But Earthlings is rather scattered.
Flakey, non-judgmental fun with UFOlogists and their late guru.
The film skirts the edges of its story like a garrulous pothead, its interviews never quite getting to the point.
Most appealing is the film's mixture of California post-War history, cults and a tinge of science fiction - an intriguing combination of elements that make it a winner.
Calling All Earthlings has so many intriguing stories to tell - and that's the problem. By bouncing back and forth between all of these stories, you don't get the complete picture of any of them.
Laugh if you want - or, conversely, give credence to the ufologists and time travelers - but to most of the people profiled this is serious stuff.
feels unfocused and scattershot
It's all faintly ridiculous, but charming, like people talking about the afterlife right before last call.
[A] brisk, sometimes glib documentary about Van Tassel and his followers.
Mystery, murder and meditation meet aliens, federal agents and time travel in Calling All Earthlings.
Most of the interviewees are, let's say, colourful and eccentric, but they all believed. See you in the stars!

The film uses synthesizer music, odd camera angles, and foggy lens effects to create a sense of mystery, but there are also times in which Berman seems to be inviting viewers to gawk at the interviewees.

Berman's film is beautifully photographed and whilst it has no great revelations or big payoffs, it's an intriguing slice of small town alternative American life, dressed up in Alien and government conspiracy tales...
Combines indigenous, tribal mythology and spirituality, with beautiful visuals and then the actual story of this guy... A really fun documentary.
This is a very enjoyable movie... All over the place, but I love these kind of subjects.
An occasionally captivating but ultimately scattered oddity.
The movie would have been better titled Working Life than Life and Work, wisely skipping discussion of Cardiff's family and friends in favor of his films.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: After Jack Cardiff's relationship with the Archers ends, the film offers precious little in the way of biographical piquancy.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: A modest pleasure.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: Essential viewing for fans of the cinematographer's craft, Craig McCall's fascinating documentary about one of the greatest cameramen of all time is a film to be cherished.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: Destined to become a perennial for film buffs everywhere, the explicitly titled Cameraman: The Life and Work of Jack Cardiff pays well deserved tribute to the legendary cinematographer who also became a respected director in his own right.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: Watching and listening to Cardiff, it is impossible not to be entranced by his knowledge, his excitement and his enthusiasm.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: Informative look at the life and career of Jack Cardiff, the talented cinematographer of Black Narcissus and director of Sons and Lovers, among many other achievements.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: A respectful documentary about the man who is arguably the greatest cinematographer of all time, Jack Cardiff.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: This is strictly talking heads fare, broken up with movie clips, stills and home movies; fortunately, Jack Cardiff's ephemera are better than yours.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: Cameraman is filled with Cardiff's achingly beautiful work, from the furious violet moods of Black Narcissus (1947) and his ballet fantasia The Red Shoes (1948) to Sylvester Stallone's agonized poses in Rambo: First Blood Part II (1985).
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: Director Alan Parker nicely describes the tightrope teeter of Cardiff's hothouse imagery: "It's great art, and then it will be kitsch, and then it will be art again." Or is he summing up cinema itself?
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: Asked if movies were a "tragic" industry, Cardiff replies, "I think it's a nonsensical thing, job, to be in, because it's full of hypocrisy, hyperbole, just about everything you can think of." Yet his example demonstrates just how worthy it can be.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: McCall approaches Cardiff with something approaching awe, though his subject views his accomplishments with the good-natured humility befitting a proper English gentleman.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: The unsurpassed work of cinematographer Jack Cardiff is gloriously featured in one of the best filmmaking documentaries ever made.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: Even with its tightly cropped approach, this is still a fascinating look at a too-neglected craft.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: Chiming in for this breezy tribute filled with tantalizing clips is a who's who of admirers, including Kirk Douglas, Lauren Bacall, John Mills and Kim Hunter.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: As captured by McCall, Cardiff has a palpable joie de vivre, an impish way with an anecdote and inventive solutions for capturing images.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: The lack of personal detail can be frustrating. Yet it suits its subject's gentlemanly reserve.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: After years of DVD special features, even dedicated buffs may be somewhat blas about a film that takes us behind the scenes to explore one man's career...but this is no ordinary documentary, and its subject is no ordinary filmmaker. Jack Cardiff was a...
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: Unfolds in a very liner fashion, and lacks a real spine, but full of some great anecdotes, and shines a light on one of cinema's quiet, under-recognized groundbreakers.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: Cameraman gives us insight into how and why movies manage to swallow us up for two hours and make us think we understand places, eras, and feelings we've never experienced.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: Cardiff was the greatest color cameraman who ever lived.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: For the cinaste, it's required viewing.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: "Cameraman" should be required viewing for anyone interested in becoming more visually literate in an ever-more-media-drenched age.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: Although we never really learn much about his life outside the movies, by the end of the film we are in awe of his work accomplishments.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: It's the images seen through Cardiff's lens that makes Cameraman such a joy to watch.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: McCall draws on Cardiff's life-long love of painting to adopt a similarly impressionistic style, brushing broad sweeps of anecdote and recollection about the cameraman on to his canvas to create a complex and emotionally engaging picture.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: His story ends in 2009, but his achievements live on, with "Cameraman" a sublime education on the masterful work of Jack Cardiff.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: For fans of Cardiff, for fans of the Archers, and for fans of all great cinema, Cameraman is a must-see.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff

review_content: Cinematographer Kirsten Johnson delivers a uniquely insightful memoir-cum-critical-treatise on the nature and ethics of her craft.
It is a remarkable document about the creative process in the service of a specific goal. It may even tap into a richer vein: what it's like to live on planet Earth.
"Cameraperson" makes a strong argument to assert the person behind the camera - who they are, how they live, and how they interact with others as a crucial focal point in the process of filmmaking.

This is what nonfiction cinema should be, a living dialog that complicates the position of the camera person in invigorating, sometimes emotionally taxing ways. This mediation, for lack of a better term, is art.
A clever and fascinating self-portrait.
Cameraperson is hypnotic, a montage of seemingly disconnected vignettes that slowly demonstrate commonalities among disparate figures around the globe.
A sumptuous and affecting visual memoir that doubles as an exploration of memory.
One gets the sense that power and meaning have been accumulated at a pace appropriately representative of Kirsten Johnson's own experiences.
Johnson doesn't purport to have the answers, but instead shows us that probing the questions and the morality is an integral part of the job.
Cameraperson's unique formal conception and restlessly interrogative assemblage forms a striking and, dare I say, original vision.
The film doesn't just work for those interested in making documentaries, but also to get to know the life and work of some of the greatest documentarians working today. [Full review in Spanish]
A perceptive, thought-provoking examination of the responsibilities and obligations of the documentary form.
A selection from 24 films by an outstanding cameraperson and human being. With all due respect to Shelly, it is documentarians who are "the unacknowledged legislators of the world".
Confidently made, with a roaming spirit that make it one of the most engaging films of the year.
Somewhat less than the sum of its parts, yet those parts are, in themselves, transfixing.
Personal footage interacts intriguingly with reportage here, sometimes making it more than the greatest-hits montage it initially seems.
A celebration of female camaraderie, and a hit-after-hit close-up record of a great cinematographer at the height of her empathic powers.
Cameraperson offers enough singular, rarely seen moments to compensate for the overall messiness.
Cameraperson is a marvelous film, and I plan to watch it again and again.
A unique and affecting memoir.

The impression all of these clips in toto is of a life fully lived, of an artist who has seen much in her life and wants to share all she has learned with the rest of the world. But Cameraperson adds up to so much more than just a personal remembrance.
Like Robert Greene's "Kate Plays Christine," it's a doc about docs that tacitly raises important questions about what we get from non-fiction films.
It's a sublime experience, one not to be missed on the big screen.
The linkages between these mostly brief snippets is somewhat haphazard, but, given the waywardness of her travels, that's appropriate.
Vivid and memorable images from the career of documentary cinematography Kirsten Johnson.
This is one of the most innovative documentaries out there, an existential collage of memories astutely edited to reveal several themes.
One of the most original, challenging and sometimes infuriating documentaries of recent times.
The movie is an extraordinary self-portrait and an existential statement: I shoot, therefore I am.
Throughout there is an awareness of a distinct sensibility behind the camera: humane, engaged, unfailingly curious.
Cameraperson is without a doubt the best documentary of 2016, and just maybe the best film of the year, period.
Enigmatic yet revelatory ...
The challenging, deeply artistic Cameraperson is also exactly that kind of documentary that would be appropriate for a festival celebrating arthouse theaters.
"Cameraperson" is a documentary unlike any other.
Small and experimental, but engrossing and enlightening, it's truly a one-of-a-kind documentary.
Cameraperson still commands your attention, hooking you with loose, tender moments.
This is autobiography in its truest form, a visual document of choices made and chances taken, and missed. It's wonderful.
Cameraperson becomes one of those rare films that snap you wide awake as soon as you begin to watch, and listen.
In Cameraperson, Johnson beautifully captures her odd life, finding in these disparate stories of other people a through-line to her own life as an observer who never forgets her own humanity.
Even those unaware of Johnson's work are gifted an unusual break from the documentary norm, exposed to slices of life that reinforce the fragility and the oddity of the human experience.
"Cameraperson" testifies to a world in which it would be clear to see that we're all connected, if only we took the time to look at one another with reverence and simply listen.
Turns out the person behind the camera is just like the rest of us.
The images she captures form the antithesis of the cold, uncaring, unblinking eye.

singularly lived-in and reflected-upon essay film draws upon her 25-year career as one of the major forces in American documentary. From shot to shot... one of the most engrossing and inventive movies of the year, if not one of the year's greatest.
Personal footage of Johnson's family and friends, woven into the documentary scenes, enhances the sense that any life is a series of amazements.
It takes a while to adjust to the seemingly scattershot collection of people and places encountered in this unusually constructed and exceptionally powerful documentary.
It is defiantly [director Kirsten Johnson's] film, her testament, and her way of looking at the world.
An intensely moving and provocatively personal consideration of what it means to carry a camera.
A graceful, deeply affecting work produced in an entirely original manner, it's one of the year's best films.
Cameraperson summons us to really think about a world that is more connected than we may realize.
Blends personal reflection with a portrait of observational documentary film-making in practice, one striking image and revealing interview at a time.
Cameraperson is not merely a grab bag of images. It pulls double duty as a theoretical essay on the cinematic apparatus itself.

Cameraperson draws our attention not just to what we're seeing, but to how we're seeing it. It encourages us to wonder how a camera operator negotiates personal space in tense, intimate, emotionally fraught situations.
Johnson is pushing the audience to see these images as a dialogue between herself and these subjects, both in the frame of her representation of them and their impact on her.
A labor of love of the highest order.
Though much of the material in Cameraperson is old, Johnson has undeniably created something new.
Cameraperson is an entertaining, engaging work, which is surely one of the finest non-fiction films of the year.
By presenting the unpredictable, the horrifying, and the hopeful through the eyes of a person who never appears on screen, Cameraperson never trivializes.
The images leave powerful impressions of the modern world in flux and filled with angst.
"Cameraperson" shows us the power of image as a tool of recording life, but also finds reasons that even in the worst situations, it's still worth living.
This is poetic cinema par excellence.
Put briefly, [Johnson] earns her juxtapositions of wildflowers and barbed wire.
An enthralling journey of shifting perspectives of the world, Cameraperson dismantles the myth of the objective documentary.
Seemingly the least exciting parts of the film maker's past work, the movie demands the viewer imagine.

The effect is entrancing: an expressionistic portrait of the itinerant lifestyle her career dictates and a subtle exploration of the ethics and practices involved in documenting the world in a truthful way.
Gives viewers a chance to sit back and ponder questions and thoughts about the nature of being human and our relationship with the world.
Although the clips of films show places thousands of miles apart, there is a common theme, of people, places and events. There is one person behind the camera who ties it all together into one story.

presents a searing, cinematic globetrot that looks at the vestiges of war, poverty and abuse-yet offsets the despair with sparks of beauty, humor, kindness. It's the human condition both at its worst...and at its best.
Johnson's compassion shines through, while the images raise vital ethical questions about the responsibilities of the nonfiction filmmaker.
A thoughtful examination of the role of the documentary-maker.
What starts out as a personal memoir builds into a thoughtful, compelling examination of the sense of responsibility that is an intrinsic part of being a documentary filmmaker.
Cameraperson is a film that somehow encompasses all of humanity and life from its first moments to very last.
This is, essentially, a very long outtakes reel.
A personal memoir that becomes a fascinating examination of the ethics and responsibilities of being a documentary film-maker.
Cameraperson is an absorbing, challenging creation.
Cameraperson is haunted - as one senses Johnson may be - by the question of whether and how much documentary filmmakers should intervene in the lives of their subjects.
Cameraperson's scrapbook of outtakes and downtime surpasses any of Johnson's greatest hits.

Kirsten Johnson has created a resonant and revealing kaleidoscope of her life behind the camera on films from Bosnian war documentaries to the Edward Snowden film Citizenfour and even a portrait of the philosopher Jacques Derrida.
Although we only see Johnson's face once, briefly, it's a detailed self-portrait of an extraordinary woman.
Fruitful themes and patterns emerge -- in, for instance, the way it intertwines Johnson's family life and the arduous scenes she witnesses during her work
At a time when the truth becomes questionable and dubious to the public at large, Cameraperson feels not only timely but relevant to the ongoing determination.
Watching Cameraperson, we take Johnson's rich images into ourselves. Having watched them, experienced them, they become entangled with us, too.
It's a thrilling puzzle of a lifetime's worth of work and you don't know if it's going to form a coherent picture.

Smart enough to make implications but let us draw our own conclusions about what these images, individually and collectively--and the art form to which they belong--mean to their photographer, to us, and to human society. [Criterion Blu-ray]
Cameraperson shows how the act of being filmed is a negotiation, and even without the initial context the emotional crux of certain sequences is wrenching.

testament to the richness of Johnson's extensive work and the importance of the documentary form, and in that regard it is a moving, important film in its own right, even though I constantly felt like I was being spun out of it by my desire to see more
A life behind the lens is examined in "Cameraperson," a fascinating, purposely disjointed documentary from director Kirsten Johnson.
Johnson's Cameraperson is nothing less than a masterpiece of documentary cinema, one that welcomes the complexities and contradictions of subjectivity.
The title almost invites a comma - "Camera, Person" - but it's one word, one concept indistinct from the other. The person doesn't stop where the camera starts.
Cameraperson is at its best when it captures instances of unexpected life.
By drawing no distinction between her personal and professional lives, [Kristen] Johnson suggests that she values her work as much as her family.
A tribute to what happens in front of the camera, how it is captured, and the eternal present of cinema.
Slow, subtle, yet ultimately mesmerizing, Cameraperson is a very personal testament to one exceptional filmmaker's love affair with her profession.
As a collection of memories, Cameraperson resonates with a unique kind of melancholy.

An autobiography of sorts, Cameraperson demands we think beyond Johnson's own extraordinary career and reflect upon our own status as observers, and the ethical and emotional responsibilities that come with it.
It's a fascinating glimpse into the work of the person behind the camera, composing and fretting, making sure every shot is aesthetically sensible.
It serves as a peek behind the curtain of documentary filmmaking, exposing even more than what's usually shown in the genre.
...this is the essay film at its finest, a personalized meandering through ideas and stories, at once autobiographical and universal.
This profile offers a rich kaleidoscope of people and situations...
Cameraperson comes alive with possibilities in every scene, mutating and evolving from moment to moment like an engrossing conversation.
This is a film I won't soon forget, and a big part of me wants other notable documentary cinematographers to make movies just like it, telling their stories in a similar fashion.
Cameraperson is one of those rare viewing experiences that may really test your patience, and only you will know if that's a good or bad thing.
Gorgeous and captivating; full of themes of war, motherhood, and oppression; this is a compelling, moving look at the creative process and the people behind the camera.

Memories shape who we are as individuals. With that context in mind, Cameraperson becomes one individual's noble attempt to capture those unforgettable moments in her life and forever memorialize them.
It is a fascinating and largely successful exploration of a form, a body of work, and of an incredibly talented cinematographer. Utterly captivating.
To explore Kirsten Johnson's immersive Cameraperson is to witness a unique, powerful memoir unfolding and unfurling.
Smart, pointed but cursory assault on "The New Censorship," college campuses and the Internet's war on stand-up comedy with edge.
It's all awfully dispiriting.
At the rate western culture is declining, Can We Take a Joke? may soon be dismissed as "hate speech.
We need silly men and women to speak truth to power because it stems the tide of dictatorship. Really. It does.
Whilst it's impressively produced, it focuses so hard on making its point that it overlooks the nuances that make the subject interesting.
Anyone who thinks political correctness has run amok needs to see this film. Anyone who thinks it hasn't needs to see it even more.
"Can We Take a Joke?" ... poses a valid question at a juncture when freedom of speech is a hot topic, especially where the Internet is concerned.
It would be better if it ... at least acknowledged the possibility that some jokes ought not be told.
Timely but hopefully not too late, it also features a good deal of laughs (albeit often bitter ones).

One of the main points of "Can We Take a Joke?" is freedom of speech. The first Amendment protects that right, but the comedians (and I) believe that freedom of speech should be elevated, especially now.
It's not the state that has turned against them; it's audiences.

There's potential swirling around "Can We Take a Joke?" as it dissects vulnerability and stupidity, but it doesn't cut deep enough, careful to avoid black holes of debate to make a grander point on the growing indignation.
Plays as if you've been invited to read half of a courtroom transcript -- the defense's half -- while skipping past redacted text that might have complicated or undermined the argument.
Interesting as it is, but it would have been much better had it really grappled with the complexities of the issue it raises rather than presenting it in a cut-and-dried way.
A cautionary tale bemoaning the chilling effect of political correctness on free speech.
The ideas presented are more complex than Can We Take A Joke? is able to fully address, but they are ideas that desperately need to be discussed.
The answer isn't necessarily one way or the other, but Can We Take a Joke? doesn't explore this societal issue with any depth or nuance.
Tackles a vital and provocative question, without a variety of different answers, it feels incomplete and unbalanced.
A sporadically interesting yet terminally unfocused documentary...
Overstates its case to a nearly comical degree, as a group of comedians claim censorship that doesn't exist (Splice Today)
[A] frequently uncomfortable but always fascinating work ...
Caniba is a cinematic rarity for a number of reasons, but most of all because it examines the topic in a modern context and with a formalism as extreme as its subject.
Caniba offers no trite explanations or condemnations of Sagawa. Instead, we are offered a small window into his reality.
One of the hardest films to watch this year, Caniba is also an intense and strangely engaging experience where art, life, horror and film intersect and move as one.
Makes a proud point of its unpleasantness.
Caniba may be tough to take in, but you'd have a difficult time finding another film that contains this much fascinating and terrible humanity.
Caniba, like most avant-garde films, refuses to be reductive and, to the frustration of many critics and audience members, leaves definitive interpretations up to the audience.
Caniba may be tough to take in, but you'd have a difficult time finding another film that contains this much fascinating and terrible humanity.
Confrontational cinema is an understatement when it comes to Caniba; it's more disturbing than any run-of-the-mill documentary about Sagawa to date.
Caniba is no Leviathan, but there is something undeniably fascinating at work.
In terms of literal visual content, Caniba isn't that extreme. But it's so real, so intimate with its repulsive subjects, that it's an especially difficult watch.
Approach is abstract aesthetic of exploring transgressive desire...into fascinating look at fundamental, eternally problematical human relationship- sibling love and rivalry.

The use of extreme close-up, often out of focus, invites us to focus on Sagawa's flesh and virtually press up against him, but unless you are innately phobic about cannibals this isn't a very interesting experience.
Ultimately, Caniba is less of a documentary than it is an art-film. It's an art-film with definite merit; it's just that your mileage is very likely to vary.
Though compelling as the subject matter is, I feel Paravel and Castaing's unrelenting close-ups and bizarre editing choices, are going to make this a "hard pass" for a lot of people.

a format that is near unwatchable: long handheld shots, drifting in and out of focus, that uncompromisingly hold the gaze of Issei and/or Jun - both now aged and ailing - in extreme close up, long after they have run out of things to say.
Perhaps it is shocking to watch, but Caniba has little to it beyond that shock value
Endlessly fascinating... there are few documentaries like Lucien Castaing-Taylor and Véréna Paravel's Caniba.
Lurid to an almost farcical degree.
As disturbing as the film can be, at the end of the day one doesn't really take much away from it.

Caniba will unquestionably be off-putting to the bulk of cinema-goers... yet, the intimate and difficult documentation approach taken by Véréna Paravel and Lucien Castaing-Taylor make it one of the most fascinating films of the year.
The film is content to depict Sagawa's morbid fascinations in a bold and unconventional way, rather than question its own; it's easier to feel and sense than to try to understand.
A weirdo documentary based on a true story of modern-day cannibalism.
Throughout Caniba, there's a singularly disquieting relationship between the filmmakers' formal experimentation and their subject.
I consider Sagawa repellent, and the movie an exercise in intellectualized scab-picking.
Caniba features no explanatory text or outside voices of any kind.
Caniba isn't the mammoth achievement of Leviathan, but the filmmakers have cobbled together another disturbing film about human loneliness.
"I can't stomach this anymore," Jun eventually remarks, as his brother pages through his illustrated confession. That makes all of us.
A fascinating film you won't ever want to see again, if you can get through it the first time.
It's puzzling to reconcile how Castaing-Taylor and Paravel simultaneously operate on such a high level ... while also strapping themselves into an aesthetic chastity belt.
Rather than sensationalizing their gruesome subject, they use it to hold a mirror up to the audience, and the disarming act of introspection should make us all a little nauseous.

Evidently, "Caniba" is not a movie for everyone, both for its theme and its presentation. However, it is also a unique experience, a truly original movie that manages to shed light into the lowest depths of human nature
Older and more experienced than his bandmates, guitarist Andy Summers was in the perfect place to observe Sting's dawning ego, but his self-excoriating observations are typical back-of-limo stuff.
Can't Stand Losing You conveys ... how the Police's genre-defying sound resulted from three distinct styles (and egos) bashing together.
Of interest to Police fans but hardly a rock-doc for the ages.
"Can't Stand Losing You" lacks that sense of the three dimensional when it comes to documenting the band, presenting a sanitized, bird's eye view of their history
A movie singularly lacking in rock-doc unpredictability and verve.
There are three stories to be told about the Police, but you're only going to hear one of them here.
An insightful peek into how the intersection of ambition, creativity, and ego can yield both brilliance and heartache.
Summers' big-screen take on those ongoing group tensions surrounding Sting's reluctance to be considered a career team player constantly strikes a by now all-too-familiar, predominantly sour, chord.
This is a needlessly dull movie that should have gone back to the drawing board.
A reminder of what this reluctant punk band that perfected a reggae-spiced pop-rock sound achieved, and the strength of the music they made.
The scope of Andy Grieve and Lauren Lazin's film is extremely limited.
This documentary, narrated by Summers through passages from his 2006 memoir One Train Later, provides a unique exploration of the trio's history.
The film is a drag - lightened up unintentionally by Summers's laughable prose.
This isn't the definitive Police documentary many will want it to be. Nor is it especially moving as a musical document.
Think of all the great documentaries you've seen about rock and roll. Now imagine a boring one. That, unfortunately, is Can't Stand Losing You: -Surviving The Police.
Jazz listeners always knew Summers was the coolest member of the Police, and that judgment is vindicated by Andy Grieve's Can't Stand Losing You: Surviving the Police.
Semi stiff voiceover readings from his memoir One Train Later make Summers sound like a hostage
The fact that the filmmakers didn't really have much to work with beyond archival and current documentary footage makes their accomplishment all the more impressive.
movie_title: Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story

review_content: Taken for what it is, Can't Stop is engaging - and beautifully done ...
movie_title: Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story

review_content: On some levels it's revealing. On others, it has as much depth as an 8 X 10 glossy.
movie_title: Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story

review_content: Behind-the-scenes look at a Bad Boy Entertainment reunion is a vanity project strictly for the fans.
movie_title: Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story

review_content: "Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story" seems more intimate and revealing than these sorts of artist-approved self-mythologies usually are - even if it fails to fill in all of Combs' blanks in 80 minutes.
movie_title: Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story

review_content: Shallow and dull. Stylish cinematography and editing alone, sans any substance, do not make a doc even remotely great. It's one of the most disappointing documentaries of the year.
movie_title: Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story

review_content: By the time Can't Stop Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story reaches its conclusion, viewers will know that the rapper/businessman wears Calvin Klein boxer briefs. And that a room in his home is devoted entirely to candy.
movie_title: Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story

review_content: As a record-label history lesson, Can't Stop, Won't Stop is incomplete. As a concert doc, it's a rough ride for the viewer.
movie_title: Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story

review_content: Can't Stop, Won't Stop will leave you with a great sense of the life and times of Diddy, even at times portraying him as just another guy next door.
movie_title: Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story

review_content: It summarises the book without dumbing the content, but remains watchable and entertaining.
Pinketty's argument, that the feudalism and exploitation that Marx was decrying 150 years ago has returned, is worth hearing out in this lively, information-packed and damning documentary.
Among the best documentaries ever about global capitalism
Justin Pemberton's film version of Thomas Piketty's landmark book on the dangers of today's yawning income inequality is more TED Talk than documentary, but it's a handy summary nonetheless.
Perhaps one of the most compelling aspects of Pemberton's documentary is a psychological study that was done with hundreds of Monopoly players...
A sleek tour of economic history over the last 400 years or so.
A nifty overview as to why everything is terrible.
Justin Pemberton's new documentary, Capital in the Twenty-First Century, takes a potentially dry academic discourse and turns it into a vibrant, cinematic experience.
A slick and engaging film that speeds through the history of modern capitalism with very few pauses for reflection.
It's a massive achievement, turning this weighty volume into enthralling cinema.

Like its source material, Pemberton's film takes a wide view of the last three centuries in order to argue that the system itself has never been as flawed as the people who try to rig it in their favor.
Pemberton... keeps everything engaging and clear, an accomplishment in a movie that devotes around a minute to explaining the "stagflation" of the 1970s.
Enlightening documentary based on prophetic, best-selling book by French economist.
A smart and eye-opening look at the current worldwide financial situation from its dubious past to its shaky future.
Based on the bestselling non-fiction book by economist Thomas Piketty, this important documentary uses a playful tone to balance its complex language, but the ultimate outlook is still pretty bleak.
The film remarkably manages to cover the development of capitalism from its 18th-century beginnings through the fallout of the 2008 housing crisis without slogging.
Given capitalism's abject failure in the face of a pandemic, the film helps us to grasp the origins of the problem even if its neo-Keynesian solution falls short.
Rarely has a high-level economics lecture felt as urgent or compelling as in this persuasive documentary.
The film prefers the illusion of intellectual rigor over the real thing.
Pemberton delivers his message with a canny pop sensibility, and, crucially, provides a few glimmers of hope.
[I]t's kind of thrilling to watch a filmmaker who's so confident in his subject matter ... and his ability to communicate such complex substance with such clarity.
Trust me this is a movie that provokes a consistent sense of "Whoa!" By the end, you'll know with greater clarity than you did before why we're in the mess we're in.
the insightful and entertaining way that Pemberton and company deliver this message of doom gives me hope that some influential eyes can be open to make that change. Nah, that is not going to happen.
A breezy treatment of the issues raised in Piketty's book, although the pop culture references are a bit too cute.

This film serves as a reminder of what lessons we have to learn from our political & economic history. It reminds us that if we don't heed the warning signs from history that led us down the wrong path, we may be doomed to go there all over again.
Attention, social justice warriors. French economist Thomas Piketty's howl-of-rage academic treatise is now a hugely engaging documentary, eye-opening and brutally entertaining. Man the barricades!
The film is essentially an illustrated lecture, and though the accompanying visuals are well-chosen and smoothly presented, the important thing is that what's said is compelling.
It all adds up to a non-revelatory but worthwhile and surprisingly watchable blend of an economics lesson, a pop-culture cocktail, and a call to action.
The extensive film clips offer familiar entertainment, convenient references, and connective tissues, but little in terms of substance.
It's a shot in the arm, a snap to attention that articulates-if you can keep up with it-just how we got to here.
Thoroughly entertaining and informative, but really shines in its charming use of movie clips to depict historical income and class disparity.
Speaks to the collective anger we all feel at the myriad systems failing us in such a critical time of need.

The new doc takes Thomas Piketty's book about the history of global wealth and power, boils it in a cinematic spoon, and injects it straight into your eyeballs. It does not feel good! But feeling good is so "pre-2016" anyway.
Capital in the Twenty-First Century offers a useful primer on the growth of capitalism over the last 300 years and looks at where we're going.
If you'd like to feel more confident about economics and you don't know where to start, this film will give you lots to get you thinking.
It is possible to agree with everything in a film and still understand that the film is bad. So it is with Capital in the Twenty-First Century.
If an in-depth examination might have been more satisfying, the film makes its points clearly and concisely.
If Piketty is a rock star, the film paints capitalism as a supergroup whose biggest hits were hugely popular, but are long in the past. New material has not been well received.
Piketty's picture is no less dismaying for being so lavishly detailed.
It's brisk, first-rate stuff, and not especially radical. I can see it being shown in schools.
As intelligent and compulsively entertaining as his previous films.
This is a typical Moore oeuvre: funny, often over the top and of dubious documentation, but with strongly made points that leave viewers much to ponder and debate after they walk out of the theater.
By returning to his roots, professional gadfly Michael Moore turns in one of his best films.
Proof of Moore's showmanship, a talent he continues to mine with every new film.
Agree or not -- and in the interests of full disclosure, I'll note that I agree more than I disagree -- Moore's voice broadens the debate in a vital way.
A collection of outrageous facts sprayed like a shotgun blast towards what Moore deems the modern Roman Empire.

You don't go to a Moore's docu for rigorous discipline or objective approach, but in returning to his liberal-populist origins, he has made another timely, provocative and entertaining work, which is also a good companion piece to his 1989 Roger & Me.

Since making "Fahrenheit 9/11" and "Sicko," Moore has polished his humanist vehicle of cinematic political agitprop to a glossy reflecting sheen with an entertaining, touching, and informative movie that's worth repeated viewings.

If Steven Spielberg is our country's best dramatic filmmaker, then surely Michael Moore is our best documentarian--which he proves in this sometimes hilariously entertaining broadside against the capitalist system.

"Harassing security guards, cheap stunts, unfunny comedy moments ... all a bit too familiar, and all a bit too distracting -- and that's a pity, because when Capitalism: A Love Story is on, it's on fire."
What's fascinating about this unfocused diatribe is that Mr. Moore, the liberal face of Middle America, has finally given up on the American audience.
Like most of his movies, Capitalism is a tragedy disguised as a comedy; it's also an entertainment.
This is vintage Moore, reflecting both the filmmaker's fondness for manipulation and his strengths as a showman.
With the global economic meltdown affecting just about everybody, the film is pertinent, hugely entertaining, and, above all, timely.
"A somewhat-droll, somewhat-glib superficial expose into how The Man is screwing you over."

Though Moore is on less solid ground when mulling vague solutions to economic woes, his message for the masses about this national 'robbery' in progress as their jobs, health care and homes go up in smoke, is loud and clear: You've been had.
A scathing indictment of modern America's "me first" approach to the social contract...an urgently important piece of work.
Capitalism's slickness, and its illusion of cumulative coherence, is actually a product of Moore's signature bait and switch, the same lack of structural integrity that mars most of his films.
Isn't it Washington that took money from the taxpayers to bail out the banks? Shouldn't Moore run his yellow crime-scene tape around the White House?
Provides lots of insights and enraging bits of information while, ultimately, coming off as somewhat amorphous.
At its best, Capitalism: A Love Story is a searing outcry against the excesses of a cutthroat time. At its worst, it's dorm-room Marxism.
Moore's ambush-and-blame methods are bad journalism. His lack of moral, political context is as questionable as ever.
Moore's scattershot is a lot more interesting than some filmmakers' focus, and many of those individual parts are classic.
The film works best when Moore sits with representatives of the 99 percent of Americans vulnerable to financial freefall.
Michael Moore fans should be able to appreciate what he does with this serious subject matter, while still keeping the movie entertaining and funny.

This is a love story, all right, but it has less to do with the flaws of capitalism than it does with Moore's unwavering fondness for the sound of his own voice, and for what he perceives as his own vast cleverness.
[A] scattershot, lazy slice of agitprop, which recycles Moore's usual slice-and-dice job on corporations, while bobbing a curtsey to the current crisis.
[Michael] Moore hasn't made a measured film because he's not looking for a measured response. He wants to get his viewers outraged and shake them out of their complacency.
Michael Moore is the Obama of documentarians.
Michael Moore paints with too-wide a conceptual brush, which in turn explains why 'Capitalism: A Love Story' goes off point so often.

There are moments in Capitalism when you're reminded of Moore's talent for shrieking truth to power. The rest of the film, however, only proves that his quixotic preachiness can make even a worthy cause feel occasionally bankrupt.
Michael Moore's hard-hitting documentary about the egregious, toxic, and rapacious spin-offs from the American obsession with unbridled capitalism and greed.
Moore's most personal film since Roger & Me: a lone, passionate man's hopeful search for answers to the very root of all of our socioeconomic problems
Moore sees our abusive relationship with capitalism as a growing plague. His movie, a genuine and welcome rabble-rouser, lays out the history of how democracy got corrupted.

Moore's choice to make "capitalism" his straw man (rather than, say, greed or Reagan-era deregulation) puts him in closer company than he might like with some pretty nasty world-historical bedfellows.

Love him or hate him, Michael Moore makes us think; he makes us talk. And if you agree with what he has to say, especially with his latest opus Capitalism: A Love Story, he can inspire you to make a difference.

Capitalism is as entertaining as Roger & Me, and its critique skewers both major political parties, calling into question the economic policies of Bill Clinton as well as Ronald Reagan.

Full of bracingly honest self-examination, raw humour and a fascinating vein of hysteria and emotion, but its real power is in the intimate examination of family ties.
Director Andrew Jarecki mounts a convincing argument but declines to work up the kind of scalding condemnation of the justice system that his findings would seem to demand.
...one comes away with a sense of angered sensationalism...Clearly, this odd and probing documentary is affecting in its seedy uncertainty.
Even more compelling is the way it tackles faulty human memories.
Uma histria absurdamente trgica e - o que  ainda mais grave - que representa um grave sintoma de uma sociedade em que a mdia ganhou poderes de polcia, juiz e executor.

The result intersperses interviews with the family and its accusers with footage from the enormous store of home video and film that the Friedmans themselves shot over 30 years to poke at both the accuracy of the charges and the elusive nature of memory.
This film is an American dream gone awry.
inspires in the viewer something which was conspicuously absent from the original trial - reasonable doubt.
Director Jarecki takes his time in presenting the divergent points of view. But even at nearly two hours, one still feels there is a lack of information.
A different kind of horror is portrayed in Capturing the Friedmans -- the disintegration of a family after the father secret life is exposed.
Grown men and women, in broad daylight and friendly company, would not lightly name some of the worst terrors of our world.
The Friedmans are a case study in family dysfunction.
Much of this information could have been delivered in a way that respected the Friedmans, even if they did not respect each other.
...an insane document, a slice of life that we probably should never have seen. But now that we have seen it, it's too late to deny its crippling poignancy...
Probing into the elusive nature of truth, through the prism of one Jewish family, this is one of the most perplexing and disturbing docus in American film history

Like the darkest pop song Billy Joel never wrote, "Friedmans" hauntingly asked how far faith goes when it comes to family, how much mercy we'd grant them based merely on our memories and how forgiveness sometimes endures years of fury before it's granted.
Captivating and intense. Mature teens+.

While with any number of... documentaries one can happily say "wait until it turns up on the small screen", with Capturing the Friedmans it is well worth sitting in the dark to find out the extent to which you think you are being deliberately kept there.

There's no doubt that the film delivers the emotional equivalent of a kidney punch, but that's as much a result of the filmmaker's attitude-better suited to entomological research-as it is to the Friedmans themselves.
This is a sad film, but nearly a must-see.
Highly informative, relatively upbeat take on global warming.
Well intended but inert.
Will the grandchildren of our grandchildren cherish our memory because we rose as one and did the right thing?
Alternative energy sources-algae, wind, and geothermal-are showcased, but Carbon Nation is most persuasive when it focuses on the individuals utilizing those supplies in their communities.
A documentary with a varied group of Americans talking about solutions to the very-real crisis of climate change.
To a point, it is refreshing to listen to positive talking heads in fields and factories. But there are so many faces that one cannot keep track of who's who and what's what.
A sobering documentary which makes a convincing case that climate change is a national security issue.
Interviewees who issue hysterical statements like "the sea ice cap is almost gone" go uncontradicted.
Mildly captivating albeit one-sided and over-simplified. It merely presents a reader's digest overview of climate change solutions [that's] more overwhelming than inspirational.

This film seems blissfully unaware that political obstructionists are paralyzing the legislative process; that deep-pocketed influence peddlers have a vested interest in maintaining the fossil fuel culture; that, in general, people resist change.
Afraid of the dullness of its subject matter, and of being lost in the swarm of patronizing eco-documentaries, Carbon Nation tries really hard to speak to the language of "young people these days."
"Carbon Nation" is an inspiring look at the many recent advances in clean energy and green technologies.

The film's hectic pace and flow has more in common with design of a kids' educational TV show, and although the information seems sometimes chaotic. it is always lively, thought-provoking, and inspirational.
Thought-provoking on a macro level in some of its interviews, but its sloppy construction, poor focus and rah-rah boosterism make for a sludgy viewing experience.
What we get is the filmic equivalent of a smiley face. But enthusiasm and sincerity don't make the hard questions go away.
A compulsively watchable if distorted history lesson
I lasted a little over halfway through before figuring that it wasn't going to get any better...

he end is a great letdown from what Mr. Preminger might have accomplished with the 1950 novel of Henry Morton Robinson. There is no strong flow of spirit through it. Even the melodrama is perfunctory and weak.
Implausible epic telling of Tom Tryon as courageous priest has great Moross score.
Thematically, Preminger's drama about internal church politics is most intriguing; too bad that the lead, Tom Tryon, is miscast.

Risible script based on a doorstop novel by Henry Morton Robinson, but handled by Preminger with tremendous panache; worth seeing just for the incredible skill and flair with which he stages the action and moves the camera.
With an hour cut out of it, this might have been a landmark picture.
This is an extremely well constructed film, made with a balance that keeps its overflowing plot line in perfect control.
It's nothing more than a kitsch take on the good and bad of the Catholic Church, but it has the chutzpah to pose as a work of art.

The cast, as a whole, is well chosen, to the point that the actors manage to overcome the holes in a story that too many times pretends to be sublime and ends up being ridiculous. [Full Review in Spanish]

Tarzan of the Apes takes us about as far into African anthropology as The Cardinal does into the inner workings of the Roman Catholic Church. A pity, since the theme might have made an interesting film.
Otto Preminger has successfully put on film a long, absorbing drama about a young Boston Irishman who becomes an ecclesiastical prince of the Roman Catholic Church.

The scenery is superb, the acting good: yet The Cardinal suggests neither the crises of the period, nor the anguished religious struggles it seeks to portray within the Catholic soul. Though the treatment is reverential, it lacks spiritual fiber.
A celebration and a lament -- a celebration of Channing's seven decades as musical comedy star, and a lament that there's really no one like her anymore.
Stalwartly upbeat
Seldom has a documentary been more aptly subtitled than Dori Berinstein's Carol Channing: Larger Than Life.
Dori Berinstein's tender but sharp portrait finds a lot of depths in the woman whom many see as a camp figure.

Wonderfully informative. It can be faulted somewhat for only viewing Channing through admiring, rose-colored glasses, but then I suppose anyone who disparages the endearingly cheery star does so at their own peril.
'Larger Than Life' proves an apt subtitle.
A terrifically entertaining, smartly constructed trip down memory lane with one of the American stage's most legendary troupers.
Enjoyable, endearing portrait of a true Broadway icon.
A bubbly 90-year-old mascot from the golden days of the American musical, this doc's subject is certainly larger than the conventional testimonial treatment she's given.
The soft touch makes perfect sense, though anyone not already lined up at the altar of old-school Broadway will find the film slower going.
The lady was - and remains - a pro, still glowin', crowin', goin' strong.
Smarten up and pay attention. The Queen of Broadway enters.
Let's hope Dolly finds her way back to center stage and never goes away again.
There's not much beyond all the fawning, but the effusively talented Channing more than deserves the gush.

Dori Berinstein's desultory, fawning profile of the nonagenarian performer devotes many of its padded 88 minutes to Channing's greatest success, playing the title yenta in Hello, Dolly! on Broadway in the 1960s.
Here's hoping another generation will take a look at a life that's even more impressive for the fact that it continues to be a work in progress.
Carol Channing: Larger than Life is like a warm cinematic hug from Shubert Alley, not to be missed by anyone with even the remotest passing interest in Channing or Broadway history.
This is a love letter to a born star and living legend that will make you laugh, cry, and be thankful that the great Channing is still here among us.
Carol Channing is 91 going on 7. That is meant as a compliment.
[Captures] the essence of Carol as one of those creatures of the theater that when you see her onstage, you know you've seen something special.
Not merely affectionate but cheerfully indulgent.
There's little sense of the Carol Channing beneath the overdone makeup - if there is one - except maybe to celebrate her fourth marriage to a high school classmate who died recently.
In her ninth decade, Carol Channing is the subject of a documentary about her incredible life and devotion to entertainment that is as delightful and effervescent as the bubbly star herself.
There's more than stage talk in Dori Berinstein's documentary: Hiding within it is a remarkable, moving love story.
As show biz documentaries go, this one is a must-see.
Still, a documentary of this nature lives and dies by the personality of its subject and Carol Channing has plenty to spare.
It's no surprise that she never really succeeded on television or film because Carol Channing truly is larger than life.
A film, and a life, worth cheering for, that will send audiences out of the theater on a cloud, whistling her iconic tunes, grinning from ear to ear.

"Cartel Land" offers up no easy answers or clear calls to action, but just a first-person account of these situations that rule the news and the hand of policy-makers, providing a deeply humanizing element to this incredibly difficult situation.
This is a film that's both timely and timeless, an examination of what appears to be an unassailable cycle of awfulness...Matthew Heineman's film feels like a peek into a gaping maw of wretchedness.
Startling access yields strong if not consistent results in "Cartel Land," Matthew Heineman's parallel portrait of vigilantes policing two different fronts of the drug war.

One person's armed vigilante is another person's guardian angel and the border between these two ideas is wafer thin and easily crossed as Matthew Heineman's beautifully shot and probing documentary shows.
The results are astounding. Cartel Land is staggering, stunning. The best documentary I've seen in a very long time.
Cartel Land [is a] spellbinding, verite documentary -- a frontline look at the murderous Mexican drug cartels.
Deftly edited, and filmed with a feel for the deadly volatility of drug violence.
In framing this predicament so vividly, in its gorgeous first scene, Cartel Land ensures that you worry about it throughout follows.
Cartel Land feels like Breaking Bad in real life, with characters even more complicated and controversial than Walter White.
There's half a great movie in Cartel Land, a gritty street-level documentary about vigilante action on both sides of the U.S./Mexico border.
A stunning work of war reportage nestled within a creaky study of ideological purity.
A movie that seeks action over analysis and could draw in the type of audience that does not regularly attend documentaries.
Cartel Land is the rare non-fiction work that routinely keeps one's nerves on edge.
Looking at the Mexican drug wars from both sides of the border, "Cartel Land" is punchy and vital but not particularly informative.
Director Matthew Heineman's camera shows the cost of lawlessness and the power - and institutional powerlessness - of the people.
Watching grandmothers face down the military trucks, we might be tempted to hail Mireles as a hero. But Cartel Land is interested in how idealism becomes corrupt.

Not really an immediate, you-are-there experience. It's a patient, detached but cryptically horrified study of a true quagmire, and the well-meaning but temperamental gun friends trying to force a straight line out of total chaos.
Cartel Land combines video journalism and ecstatic beauty filmmaking to devastating effect, like real life framed as a breathlessly paced thriller.
Director Matthew Heineman's Cartel Land is a brave exercise in and a fascinating piece of journalism.
Even though it has an uneven narrative, it's worth watching. [full review in Spanish]
Heinman's uncompromising camera work makes this a brutal documentary. [full review in Spanish]
What's missing is a directorial point of view, including about vigilante groups, the so-called war on drugs, and Mexican and American policies and politics.
What you're left with is the sickening realization that this cycle of violence is as hopeless as it is unstoppable.
Cartel Land is essential viewing because it is enmeshed in the haze of reality, not the simplicity of fiction. There are no easy answers.
...an eye opening look at organized vigilantism.
All vigilante groups are not created equal; here, the nuances sometimes get lost.
A stroke of genius intensify the bitterness of this brutal narrative. [full review in Spanish]
Cartel Land asks: Is law enforcement really fighting against drug gangs? [full review in Spanish]
Captures the positives of [organized vigilantes'] grassroots community organizing, as well as their far scarier prejudices that can lead to anarchy and corruption.

Not for the faint of heart, it sometimes puts its cameras right it the middle of gun battles, for a result that is extremely dramatic even if it also leaves a number of important questions regrettably unanswered.
Heineman's close-up look at the war on drugs bathes the situation in the personal stakes of the figures enmeshed in these thorny dilemmas on a daily basis.
Heineman was lucky to come out of this project intact. After viewing Michoacan's mayhem from a more comfortable distance, Cartel Land viewers may feel similarly fortunate.
[I]mpressive filmmaking in the service of dispiriting fact, figures on both sides of the law saying that lawlessness and corruption cannot and will not end.
Surveys two different frontiers of the disordered relationship between Mexico and the United States without trying to deliver moral lessons.
As a documentary, it's pretty damned depressing. As a parable of human nature, it's vital.
It's nothing short of The Wild Bunch meets Traffic, sans the cathartic denouement.
Although the film has its shortcomings and simplifications, it's a bleakly persuasive view of a decades-long combat that respects no boundaries, and seems to hold no prospect of surcease.
A jaw-dropping documentary about two vigilante groups, on opposite sides of the U.S.-Mexico border, trying to stave off Mexican drug cartels.

If the key to price in real estate is "location, location, location," the key to success in vérité-style documentaries is "access, access, access." Which is what "Cartel Land" has in compelling amounts.
Cartel Land offers a chilling glimpse into a world of violence and vigilantism.
Cartel Land is an unapologetically cinematic take on the crime documentary -- breathless, intense, spectacular.
A worthwhile report on a pressing humanitarian issue.
It's one thing to invent a vigilante drama as darkly perfect as this, it's another to capture it as it actually unfolds.
Some documentaries are about answers. Others are about questions. "Cartel Land" is about the hazy territory in between ...
Heineman earns major props for his courage under fire while also capturing striking and indelible images.
"Cartel Land" reveals a culture that spans the border, full of death and dismaying behavior on both sides, but thriving all the same.
Ultimately, Cartel Land hampers its own efforts to meaningfully address its subject.
The most impressive aspect of "Cartel Land" is the trust and access Heineman's crew obtained to the two central figures of his report.
By the end of Heineman's rattling 98 minutes, the war on drugs seems more than ever like a war destined to go on forever before being lost on every side.
As the film demonstrates, this is far from a black-and-white situation.
The overall impact is harrowing and, considering the subject matter, appropriately hopeless.

Without passing moral judgments on either group, "Cartel Land" provides a vivid illustration of the dangers inherent whenever a government fails to meet its citizens' needs to the extent that they take matters into their own hands.

What starts as a rousing look at "good" citizens fighting to rid their communities of roving gangs of gun-toting thugs, slowly evolves into a disturbing study of human nature, as the right intentions go frighteningly wrong.
One of the year's most important documentaries ...
Absolutely essential viewing, as vital and unsettling a documentary as you're likely to see.
Much of the documentary Cartel Land, an immersion into the Mexican drug traffickers and citizen vigilantes, is hair-raisingly intense.
Filmmaker Matthew Heineman places himself in the line of fire more than once in this shocking and eye-opening real-life expose of the illegal drug industry in Mexico.
I found my heart pounding as Heineman, often with bullets flying all around, manages to film sequences straight out of a fictional movie or TV show.
Cartel Land's narrative and Hollywood shine make this doc a gripping watch... This is a film of real stakes, real deaths, and real conflict.
The production is precise in its nightmarish summation of futility, giving this necessary education an inevitable severity.
This raw and compelling (if necessarily incomplete) documentary focuses on the recent battles between drug cartels and vigilantes along the Arizona-Mexico border.
Vigilantism on both sides of the Mexican-U.S. line is the subject of Mathhew Heineman's powerful but curiously diffuse documentary.
Even if it leaves you wanting more, "Cartel Land" deserves to be seen.
Chilling and compelling, ripped from today's headlines...
Cartel Land is a brilliantly exposed snapshot of a hugely complicated situation.
Heineman and his crew gain a terrifying level of access, giving us front-row seats to the drug war.
An amazing look at the new world of methamphetamine manufacture and distribution and the losing battle locals are fighting against it.

[Heineman] needed either to find a compelling reason to keep the American vigilantes in this film, or keep the focus entirely on the genuinely gripping material in Mexico and the far more complex protagonist in Mireles.
A vivid and sometimes infuriating portrait of a seemingly unwinnable battle.
There are scenes here unlike anything you've seen. Timely, thoughtful and supremely well-constructed, we'd be stunned if this isn't the doc to beat on Oscar night.
The real revelations of the film are in Michoacán with Mireles, but don't expect solutions, or clear lines between good and evil, to emerge.
Lacks the necessary perspicacity, objectivity and trenchancy.
Thoroughly researched, occasionally engrossing, but ultimately frustrating.
There's no doubting Heineman and his crew's audacity as they venture close to the line of fire, but the commitment to observing dispassionately at all times starts to feel a bit like a cop-out.
Matthew Heineman's documentary about the Mexican drug wars plays like a real-life version of some grim Sam Peckinpah Western in which violence and corruption have become endemic.
The road to hell, as paved with best intentions, has never looked better.
Jaw-droppingly intense ...
Horribly real, an urgent and alarming account of a crisis so hellishly labyrinthine it's hard to see how anyone can escape its widening web of violence, extortion and corruption.
Heineman goes through the gates of Hell and comes back empty-handed.

Cartel Land is not a fun watch but it is a compelling one. It has all the larger than life characters, gang violence and government corruption of a fictional crime drama made horribly tragic by its reality.
Matthew Heineman's powerful documentary challenges our assumptions of loyalty -- like you, like us? -- as well as of good and evil.
One of the most astonishing films on the ruthless drug cartels.

This documentary about the problems and limitations of vigilante justice includes some impressive hand-held camera work, indicating bravery during firefights south of the border, and stamina while climbing very rugged terrain along the border.
Frightening, fly-on-the-wall documentary following the efforts of vigilantes to wrest control of border towns back from ruthless drug cartels operating along the Rio Grande.

Like most documentaries about the Mexican drug wars, this has nothing to say about the social and political context. It is meant for visceral entertainment and as such reflects the aesthetic of Kathryn Bigelow--the executive producer.
Let's try justice my way
The longer it goes, the easier it becomes to be turned off by the frequent graphic violence that so frequently punctuates the narrative.
More than a great documentary, this is a great piece of journalistic work. [Full review in Spanish]
A real-life action thriller, a terrifying, companion piece to Sicario. Do we want the wild West in the 21st century? Because that's what we've got.
Cartel Land is surprisingly effective in its on-the-ground approach.
Cartel Land shows us things we haven't seen before, and its last act contains startling revelations. But the film is also pretty tacky in its numbingly high-octane presentation
A little bit of critical distance could surely only have helped make this is a real discussion of the issues, not just a vivid depiction of them.
Cartel Land provides a solid cinematic structure that allows two parallel storylines to intersect effortlessly.

An examination of whether vigilante justice - no matter how well-intentioned at the start - is doomed, ultimately, to become just another example of would-be good guys falling prey to the lure of egotism and/or big money.
An almost unbelievably intimate piece of cinematic journalism
The run-and-gun style and Heineman's jaw-dropping access will keep your heart pounding through this examination of the current War on Drugs.
Raw, brutal, and ambitious, Cartel Land may be a real life story, but its limited scope in truly exploring the ideas it raised left me wanting more.
It's really hard to take your eyes off Cartel Land-even when you might need to (re: graphic images of cartel victims).
Cartel Land vividly presents the gulf between fantasies of vigilante heroism, and how they often harrowingly -- if not bitterly -- play out in reality.
Most of the anecdotes (and there are many) are as juicy and compelling as they are plain-old horrifying.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: With considerable attention to detail, the doc takes the view that Congress is influenced by cash. What a surprise!
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Alex Gibney's new documentary on how Jack Abramoff sleazed his way to power is not just an incisive look at an insurgent branch of the conservative movement, but a strong return to form.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Move over, Tea Party revelers. Abramoff's already been there, done that in this political porn in the raw. Nearly casting himself as loathsome lobbyist in his own Favor Factory reality show, with a perpetual smirk and a Blackberry in each hand.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: It makes plain, from the outset, its position as an expos-cum-condemnation of our political system as inherently flawed with regard to the relationship between lobbyists, politicians, and policy.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Audiences already numb to the staggering amount of America's ongoing governmental corruption will have a tough time digesting the cynical climate of greed that allows Abramoff's brand of manipulation of congressmen and senators to still go on under a radi
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: If Alex Gibney's documentary on the notorious lobbyist Jack Abramoff is a little dense, it's with good reason. This now convicted felon mover and shaker played his power in a lot of arenas. And his story is not an easy one to tell.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Casino Jack and the United States of Money is indispensable viewing.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: If the inner workings of Washington, D.C. interest you, especially in terms of how politicians and lobbyists work the system to make money, Gibney's latest can be accepted as a fine addition to his filmography.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: I don't know about you, but the moment I hear the word lobbyist, my brain glazes over. Casino Jack and the United States of Money woke my brain, and my outrage, right up.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: The big absence here is the man himself; Gibney couldn't get the jailed Abramoff on camera, either due to unwillingness or a Justice Department intervention. Whatever the reason, it's crippling.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: I don't know which is worse, how much money was taken from the unsuspecting clients or how little it took to get crucial support from key members of Congress.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Gibney is as good as it gets at making complicated political material come alive on screen.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Fascinating viewing as you start to root against the dastardly villains who had more ego than ethics.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Gibney has enough material for a dozen movies here, but his attempt at an overview, however unwieldy, paints one hell of a nauseating picture.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: It should be required viewing for anyone who wants to vote in the 2010 election and has teabags stapled to their person.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Entertainingly and usefully ties all the far-flung pieces together to comprehensibly show his consistent pattern of corrupt operations that wasn't the lone rotten apple.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Mr. Abramoff may be in prison, but there are no signs that his kind of high-powered lobbying, which one talking head describes as "legalized bribery," is a thing of the past.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Ultimately, it becomes a Rorschach test of the viewer's cynicism: Does it shock you? You must not live in Washington, read the newspaper or follow politics. Are you horrified? Congratulations, and now wise up.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Watching Casino Jack and the United States of Money made me sick to my stomach.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Occasionally drags and offers nothing surprising or new, yet it remains intriguing and provocative thanks to Gibney's easy-to-follow and comprehensive assessment of Abramoff's rise and fall to power.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: It really is compelling.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: It's very entertaining as well as appalling.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Casino Jack is audience-friendly without turning into a Michael Moore-ish clown show.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Unable to film Jack Abramoff in prison, Casino Jack finds a series of ingenious solutions -- elegant, funny, and preposterous ways to sort out the man's thinking and contexts.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Invokes as much mild outrage as a presentation of lobbying gone wild can. It's not exactly an earth-shattering revelation.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: It's a story well told, but Abramoff's voice is missing: Gibney interviewed him in prison but could not film him. You wonder what this sweet-talker might say for himself, looking back over that long, ugly money trail.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: The crimes of conservative superlobbyist Jack Abramoff are already receding into the hopeless murk of congressional history, so this epic documentary by Alex Gibney is even more welcome for its reach.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Those compelled by secrecy in Washington will find a devastating, disturbing examination of political back-scratching.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: It's an informative, interesting documentary that just barely comes together enough and tells an important enough story to merit a look, but it's not the film that it could have been.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: Superlobbyist, Republican wheeler-dealer, and convicted felon Jack Abramoff may seem like old news right now -- he's been trumped by Bernie Madoff et al. -- but what he represents, alas, is all too evergreen.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money

review_content: The snarky tone, use of musical puns and jokey graphics (was Keith Olbermann an executive producer?) undermine the impact of the story.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money
